Ivysaur.comments:
Other Options

Giga Drain is an alternative Grass-type STAB move that can be used when sun isn't up. It also provides recovery, making Ivysaur harder to revenge kill with the likes of Sawk and Rotom. However, Ivysaur shouldn't be used when sun isn't up and the lack of power is pretty significant, missing some crucial OHKOs after a Growth such as Kangaskhan and Silvally. Sleep Powder can take advantage of a check, but standard Ivysaur can't fit it. Ivysaur can also run an utility set with a 252 HP / 160 Def / 96 Spe EV spread and a Bold nature, which can check common threats including Rhydon, Sawk, and Tangela.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like defensive Rapidash and Ninetales avoid the OHKO from +2 Sludge Bomb and can OHKO Ivysaur back with their powerful STAB moves.

Faster Choice Scarf and Priority Users: Even with Chlorophyll, Ivysaur gets outsped by common Choice Scarf users like Manectric, which can revenge kill it with Overheat. Powerful priority users likes Kangaskhan and Shiftry can take out a weakened Ivysaur.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Ivysaur is a very threatening sweeper and wallbreaker in sun. Thanks to its great Eviolite-boosted bulk, Toxic immunity, and resistances for common attackers such as Thwackey and Sawk, it can easily find opportunities to set up with Growth in sun. The listed attacks perfectly cover the whole metagame, with Weather Ball hitting Pokemon the likes of Klinklang, Skuntank, and Frosmoth that can take on Ivysaur's STAB moves. Chlorophyll with a Timid nature lets Ivysaur outspeed prominent Choice Scarf users like Rotom, Sawk, and Silvally in sun.

Ivysaur only fits on dedicated sun teams, so staples of this archetype make for great partners. For example Uxie and Liepard are two amazing sun setters. Other Chlorophyll users such as Shiftry, Leafeon, and Exeggutor appreciate Ivysaur weakening their common checks like Fire-types and Altaria, as well as beating Poison-types like Skuntank and Silvally-Poison thanks to Weather Ball, in order for them to clean late-game. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash also enjoy sun support and help Ivysaur and the other Chlorophyll users with opposing Fire-types.

Butterfree.comments:
Other Options

Tinted Lens makes Butterfree very threatening but also much less reliable. If running Tinted Lens, Bug Buzz is far better than Hurricane, as Hurricane is likely to miss without Compound Eyes. Giga Drain provides Butterfree with recovery and lets it hit Rock-types, but it doesn't deal much damage and is less useful than Hurricane and Bug Buzz.

Checks and Counters

Priority: Butterfree's low Defense stat makes it very vulnerable to being heavily damaged by incoming priority moves like Shiftry's Sucker Punch and Kangaskhan's Fake Out.

Steel- and Rock-types: Steel-types like Klinklang, Perrserker, and Galarian Stunfisk and Rock-types such as Coalossal and Rhydon wall Butterfree's Hurricane and OHKO it. However, they struggle against Leftovers sets setting up multiple times with the combination of Substitute + Sleep Powder and being put to sleep in general.

Electric-types: Choice Scarf Electric-types like Rotom formes easily revenge kill Butterfree at +1, putting an end to its sweeping attempt. Bulkier Electric-types like Rotom-S can take care of Butterfree in a pinch, easily living a boosted hit.

Choice Scarf Users: Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Rotom, and Silvally exploit Butterfree's mediocre Speed and revenge kill it.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description:
Compound Eyes Butterfree's accurate Sleep Powder complements Quiver Dance, making it quite the offensive threat. Although its average Speed and mediocre Special Attack makes Frosmoth seem like a better option in comparison, Butterfree does have a few tricks up its sleeve. Compound Eyes makes Sleep Powder and Hurricane far more threatening with very low chances of missing. Substitute takes advantage of Sleep Powder to provide Butterfree with an extra layer of protection, allowing it to safely use Quiver Dance multiple times. While its 4x weakness to Stealth Rock makes Heavy-Duty Boots seem better, Leftovers makes Butterfree much more consistent if your team has reliable entry hazard removal and prevention.

Butterfree is most effective late-game when a lot of the opposing team is weakened, and it can come in and set up with Quiver Dance to win. However, it is also tremendously threatening in the early-game, especially with Leftovers before Stealth Rock is up. It can set up on and beat common leads such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk and open the way for teammates such as Rotom and Frosmoth. Using Butterfree early-game lets it cripple walls with Sleep Powder. Slow wallbreakers like Flapple, Perrserker, and Alcremie appreciate Butterfree's Sleep Powder, allowing them to safely switch in. In return, Butterfree appreciates their damage making it much easier to KO bulky Pokemon such as Clefairy, Wishiwashi, and Miltank. Butterfree is very frail, and it struggles with Choice Scarf users such as Rotom, Silvally, and Sawk without a Substitute set up. It appreciates bulky teammates like Tangela, Gurdurr, and Uxie, which can come in on opposing attacks, primarily priority attacks that Butterfree is very weak to. When using Leftovers, entry hazard removers like Altaria, Coalossal, and Articuno are needed in order to make sure Butterfree can get onto the field. Entry hazards set by Pokemon like Rhydon, Qwilfish, and Miltank wear down opposing Pokemon for Butterfree, making it easier to sweep.

Clefairy.comments:
Other Options

Aromatherapy allows Clefairy to function as a cleric. Encore can be used to lock opposing setup sweepers such as Frosmoth and Ninetales into an unfavorable move, but Clefairy generally has trouble fitting the move. Thunder Wave is an alternative to Toxic that cripple Poison- and Steel-types like Qwilfish and Perrserker. Teleport allows Clefairy to pivot and retain momentum, but it is incompatible with Soft-Boiled and forces Clefairy to rely on Wish or Moonlight. Clefairy can also opt for a fully physically defensive spread to better check foes like Sawk and Silvally-Dark. A set with Calm Mind is also an option, although Clefairy is outclassed by Alcremie in this role.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Skuntank, and Qwilfish force out Clefairy with their Poison-type STAB attacks and use that opportunity to set entry hazards or set up.

Steel-types: Although they dislike Knock Off, Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker are able to take advantage of Clefairy.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash resist Moonblast and can overwhelm Clefairy. However, they heavily dislike Knock Off removing their Heavy-Duty Boots and are susceptible to Toxic.

Strong Physical Attackers: Physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Thwackey exploit Clefairy's mediocre Defense and threaten to KO it.

Knock Off: Although Clefairy resists Knock Off, it is reliant on Eviolite to maintain its bulk; otherwise, it risks being overwhelmed by threats it is supposed to check, like Choice Specs Basculin and Thievul.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Clefairy is a notable special wall in ZU, capable of checking foes like Thievul and Rotom and absorbing status from the likes of Wishiwashi and Altaria thanks to Magic Guard. Moonblast targets Dark- and Fighting-types like Alolan Persian, Liepard, and Sawk. Alternatively, Seismic Toss provides consistent damage output against foes that resist Moonblast, such as Qwilfish and Rapidash, while also breaking Substitute from threats like Frosmoth and Articuno. Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Qwilfish, Perrserker, and Rapidash. Toxic wears down problematic foes that can take advantage of Clefairy, like Rapidash and Alcremie, and it synergizes with Seismic Toss, allowing Clefairy to take down most walls.

Clefairy fits best on balance and stall teams as a specially defensive wall. Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Alolan Dugtrio can threaten Poison-, Steel-, and Fire-types that Clefairy has a hard time against. In return, it is able to take on foes like Articuno and Wishiwashi and absorb Toxic and burns from Scald. Physical walls such as Tangela and Cramorant are great partners for Clefairy, helping cover for its mediocre Defense and checking powerful wallbreakers such as Perrserker and Kangaskhan. Knock Off absorbers like Alolan Persian and Qwilfish can help Clefairy preserve its Eviolite, which is crucial to keep checking special attackers. Wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Cinccino, and Kangaskhan benefit from Clefairy's ability to whittle down defensive cores with Knock Off and Toxic.

Ninetales.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower is an alternative to Fire Blast that provides more accuracy and consistency, but it is significantly weaker. Substitute can be used to avoid status from foes like Pyukumku and Altaria, while Agility helps Ninetales clean better late-game; however, Ninetales generally prefers retaining Scorching Sands.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant can take Energy Ball and retaliate with a powerful Water-type STAB attack. However, they have difficulty checking Ninetales after Nasty Plot. Pyukumuku is notable, as it ignores Nasty Plot with Unaware and can stall Ninetales with Toxic + Recover.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Piloswine and Rhydon can threaten Ninetales with their STAB moves, but they should be wary of Energy Ball.

Revenge Killers: Foes such as Manectric, Cinccino, and Choice Scarf Sawk can outspeed and revenge kill Ninetales. It is also susceptible to priority from Kangaskhan, Gurdurr, and Shiftry if it is weakened.

Status: Ninetales is vulnerable to being worn down by Toxic from foes like Pyukumuku and Miltank, while Thunder Wave from Qwilfish cripples its Speed and makes it much easier to revenge kill.

Dragon-types: Altaria and Appletun resist or are immune to Ninetales's moves and can threaten it with a strong attack or status.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Ninetales is a notable sweeper thanks to its access to Nasty Plot, excellent coverage options, and good Speed tier. Nasty Plot lets Ninetales break through bulky walls such as Clefairy with its powerful Fire Blast and clean weakened teams. Energy Ball targets Water-types like Wishiwashi and Poliwrath and Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk. Scorching Sands is Ninetales's best move against Qwilfish and opposing Fire-types like Rapidash and Coalossal.

Ninetales fits on balance and offense teams as a mid- and late-game wallbreaker and revenge killer. Wallbreaking partners such as Rotom and Cinccino complement Ninetales; Rotom is able to threaten Water-types and safely bring in Ninetales with Volt Switch, while Cinccino is able to handle specially defensive walls like Pyukumuku and Miltank that wall Ninetales. In return, they benefit from its ability to handle Tangela and Eldegoss. Grass-types like Tangela and Eldegoss are also good partners, handling problematic foes like Stunfisk and Piloswine. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie, Cofagrigus, and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Heavy-Duty Boots and prevent Ninetales from being worn down by entry hazards; Uxie and Cofagrigus can also take on revenge killers such as Kangaskhan and Choice Scarf Sawk, while Qwilfish can provide entry hazard support to wear down foes like Piloswine and Poliwrath. Cleaners such as Frosmoth and Calm Mind Alcremie can take advantage of Ninetales's wallbreaking to set up and clean late-game.

Persian-Alola.comments:
Other Options

A Nasty Plot set can be used, but Alolan Persian lacks power even at +2 and has mediocre coverage.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: While they dislike Knock Off and Toxic, Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Gurdurr easily force Alolan Persian out. Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds Alolan Persian and prevents it from pivoting.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types easily come into Alolan Persian's Dark-type STAB attacks and force it out. Due to Sweet Veil, Alcremie can turn non-Toxic Alolan Persian into setup fodder; Rest Alcremie is even able to turn Toxic Alolan Persian into setup fodder. While Clefairy hates Knock Off, Alolan Persian cannot meaningfully damage it in any way and fears heavy damage from its Moonblast.

Residual Damage: Alolan Persian's lack of recovery makes it extremely susceptible to residual damage, especially after losing its Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Special Attackers: Special attackers such as Skunktank and Ninetales easily exploit Alolan Persian's low special bulk.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description:
Parting Shot in combination with Alolan Persian's fantastic Speed and good Fur Coat-boosted bulk allows it to function as an effective bulky pivot. Foul Play threatens physical attackers, notably setup sweepers such as Rapidash and Silvally-Poison. Toxic wears down Pokemon that don't fear Alolan Persian's attacks such as Alcremie and Tangela, but Taunt can be used to prevent entry hazards from setters such as Qwilfish and Uxie and distrupt recovery attempts from walls such as Miltank and Articuno. Knock Off cripples almost every switch-in, notably strong counters such as Clefairy and Gurdurr.

Alolan Persian fits best on offensive teams as a way to generate momentum and setup opportunities, although defensive teams can also make use of its pivoting capabilities. Wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Kangaskhan and Frosmoth make good partners due to their ability to muscle through walls Alolan Persian struggles with such as Clefairy and Altaria; in turn it provides them with safe entry. In particular, Rotom is an especially good partner due to the duo's type synergy and effective pivoting. Entry hazard setters such as Piloswine and Qwilfish also greatly appreciate Alolan Persian's ability to safely get them on the field. Other walls such as Altaria and Tangela benefit from Alolan Persian crippling targets such as Gurdurr and Sawk, which makes checking them easier, and bringing pivot support with Parting Shot, which also weakens opposing attackers. In return, these walls make up for Alolan Persian's lack of reliable recovery and mediocre bulk.

Rapidash.comments:
Other Options

Solar Blade is an option on sun teams to surprise opposing Water- and Ground-types in one moveslot, but it is generally niche and requires dedicated support. Flame Charge allows Rapidash to boost its Speed and prevents it from being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Although they dislike status and Wild Charge, Water-types like Wishiwashi, Qwilfish, and Poliwrath are able to handle Rapidash with their Water-type STAB attacks.

Rock- and Ground-types: Rock- and Ground-types like Coalossal and Rhydon threaten Rapidash and force it out. However, they must be wary of High Horsepower and a potential Will-O-Wisp if they are not immune to it.

Dragon-types: Dragon-types like Altaria and Appletun resist or are immune to Rapidash's Flare Blitz and coverage options. Although Appletun dislikes Toxic, Altaria can shrug off status thanks to Natural Cure.

Residual Damage: Toxic and Knock Off from Pokemon that Rapidash is supposed to check, like Articuno, Tangela, and Thwackey, can hinder its utility and effectiveness.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Utility Rapidash is a solid check to prominent threats in ZU such as Frosmoth, Thwackey, and Articuno. High Horsepower targets Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal as well as Pokemon like Ninetales and Qwilfish. Toxic places checks such as Wishiwashi and Pyukumuku on a timer, while Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Piloswine, and Silvally formes. Morning Sun allows Rapidash to remain healthy throughout a match to continually soft check foes. Flash Fire provides an immunity to Fire-type moves, which allows Rapidash to handle Ninetales.

Utility Rapidash fits on bulky offense and balance teams as a check to many of ZU's prominent offensive threats. Tangela is an amazing partner, as it covers problematic Water- and Ground-types like Wishiwashi and Rhydon. In return, Rapidash is able to take on opposing Fire- and Ice-types and Eldegoss, which give Tangela trouble. This core is often paired with special walls like Clefairy and Wishiwashi to handle foes like special Basculin and Rotom. Ice-types like Frosmoth and Articuno can threaten the aforementioned Ground-types while also dealing with the problematic Altaria. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Rapidash's Heavy-Duty Boots, which is crucial to letting it consistently switch in.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance Rapidash is a wallbreaker and cleaner that faces competition with Ninetales as a Fire-type setup sweeper. High Horsepower targets foes like Rhydon, Coalossal, and Qwilfish. Morning Sun provides Rapidash with reliable recovery, mitigating some of the recoil from Flare Blitz and letting it consistently switch into foes like Frosmoth and Ninetales. Wild Charge handles opposing Water-types like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant.

Swords Dance Rapidash functions best as a mid-game wallbreaker that can also double as a late-game cleaner. Grass-types like Tangela and Thwackey can help weaken Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Wishiwashi, Rhydon, and Piloswine; in return, they appreciate Rapidash forcing out Skuntank and Silvally-Poison and handling Tangela. Ice-types like Frosmoth, Articuno, and Jynx threaten Dragon- and Water-types like Altaria, Appletun, and Poliwrath. Entry hazard support from Rhydon and Qwilfish is valuable, wearing down physically bulky foes like Wishiwashi and Gurdurr into KO range. Likewise, special wallbreakers like Rotom, Basculin, and Skuntank can also pressure the aforementioned physical walls.

Rhydon.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb and Adamant can be used on the offensive set to break past physically defensive Tangela, as Megahorn boosted by Swords Dance has an 81.3% chance to OHKO; however, the loss of bulk causes Rhydon to fare worse against most other matchups, and Life Orb sets alone are outclassed by Lycanroc-M due to Rhydon's lack of speed. Physically defensive sets are also a viable option if a team is in desperate need of a physical wall. However, opting for Special Defense investment tends to be preferable so that Rhydon can take on neutral special attacks decently well. High Horsepower should be used over Earthquake if Rhydon is paired with Thwackey.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tangela, Gourgeist-S, and Thwackey threaten Rhydon out, although they dislike switching into Toxic, and Tangela must be wary of offensive sets if it loses its Eviolite. Thwackey's Grassy Glide can always revenge kill Rhydon even after it has used Rock Polish.

Water-types: Wishiwashi and Poliwrath can all reliably switch into Rhydon and threaten it out with their STAB moves. Other Water-types like Basculin and Cramorant easily outspeed and can OHKO Rhydon, but cannot risk switching into Rhydon's attacks. All of these Pokemon must also be wary of Toxic.

Faster Special Attackers: Due to Rhydon's common weaknesses and naturally low Special Defense, Pokemon with a high Special Attack stat such as Ninetales, Frosmoth, and Jynx can all reliably revenge kill Rhydon, although they require a free turn to safely switch in.

Passive Damage: Residual damage from status and entry hazards punishes Rhydon heavily due to its lack of recovery. Burns in particular are problematic, as they make it nearly impossible for offensive sets to wallbreak, while defensive sets cannot reliably threaten out hazard removal.

Fighting-types: Throh and Gurdurr have no issues switching into Rhydon's attacks, and Sawk can easily revenge kill Rhydon.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Rhydon is one of the premier Stealth Rock users, as its solid typing allows it to easily threaten out most common hazard control foes such as Altaria, Rotom-S, and Coalossal. Rhydon can also opt for Rock Blast over Stone Edge for a move with better accuracy and the ability to break past Substitutes of Rotom, Articuno, and Uxie. Swords Dance lets Rhydon set up on passive walls and force out Altaria more reliably as it would attempt to Roost stall Rhydon after landing a Toxic. Alternatively, Roar synergizes well with Stealth Rock and phazes foes like Alcremie and Uxie, thereby preventing Rhydon from becoming setup fodder. Toxic cripples physical walls such as Tangela and Gourgeist-S that often switch into Rhydon. 84 Speed allows Rhydon to outspeed Pokemon with base 50 Speed, such as Piloswine. 16 Attack EVs and an Adamant nature greatly increase Rhydon's power while also allowing for enough Special Defense investment to reliably check Rotom and Skuntank.

Rhydon's 4x weakness to Water- and Grass-type attacks means it must rely on teammates such as Tangela, Thwackey, and Altaria to switch in to such attacks. Qwilfish can form great hazard stacking cores with Rhydon, Qwilfish also having access to Taunt to shut down Defoggers. Gourgeist also serves as a good partner for Rhydon, as it can cover for Rhydon's Fighting-type weakness, while Rhydon can switch into Fire-type attacks. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash appreciate Rhydon's abilities to lure in Grass-types and to counter Altaria.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
With a monstrous base 130 Attack stat and access to Swords Dance, Rhydon makes for a solid wallbreaker. The combination of Earthquake and Stone Edge covers the majority of ZU for at least neutral damage. Stealth Rock is a solid option if your team is in need of a Stealth Rock setter, while Rock Polish boosts Rhydon's Speed and turns it into a late-game win condition as well. Megahorn can also be used, as it allows Rhydon to hit Tangela, one of its most common switch-ins, for super effective damage, even threatening to OHKO Tangela after a Swords Dance boost. Megahorn also threatens the likes of Uxie, Lurantis, and Eldegoss.

Rhydon pairs very well with physical attackers that have access to Knock Off such as Sawk and Thwackey, as they can lure in Tangela and remove its Eviolite, so that Rhydon can threaten it with Stone Edge or Megahorn. Qwilfish makes for good partners, as it forms a solid hazard core with Rhydon, which also aids its wallbreaking attempts. Rhydon should be paired with pivots such as Rotom, Wishiwashi, and Uxie to provide safe setup opportunities. Rhydon will require teammates that can handle its 4x weakness to Grass- and Water-type attacks; some good options for this role include Altaria, Articuno, and Tangela.

Tangela.comments:
Other Options

Tangela can run an offensive spread with a Modest nature, which makes it less passive while still being able to check most physical attackers. However, Tangela's coverage is narrow and can be easily walled; it's also forced to use Synthesis more often to maintain its HP. Stun Spore is an alternative over Sleep Powder or Toxic to paralyze foes, but crippling a foe with sleep or poison is usually preferred.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Tangela has an abysmal special bulk and can be 2HKOed by almost any unresisted special attack. In particular, special attackers like Rotom-S and Skuntank have a great matchup against Tangela and can easily OHKO it. Strong special wallbreakers like Basculin are even able to break through Tangela with resisted attacks.

Item Removal: Without its Eviolite, Tangela is unable to reliably counter some physical attackers like Sawk. This is troublesome, as Tangela is often the preferred switch-in for common Knock Off users such as Sawk, Shiftry, and Cinccino.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales can break through Tangela's huge physical bulk with their super effective STAB moves. However, they dislike losing their Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Ice-types: Articuno and Jynx threaten Tangela with their super effective STAB moves, while Frosmoth can use Tangela as setup fodder. They have to be wary of getting their item removed by Knock Off, though.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Tangela is an amazing physical wall thanks to its immense Eviolite-boosted physical bulk backed by Regenerator. This combination allows it to consistently absorb the hits of physical attackers such as Rhydon, Sawk, and Kangaskhan and regain the lost health by switching out. Giga Drain is the preferred STAB move for its additional recovery. Leaf Storm can be used instead for a powerful nuke, especially against Knock Off users like Sawk and Alolan Persian; the Special Attack drop isn't that crippling, as Tangela enjoys pivoting to regain HP with Regenerator. Knock Off lets Tangela cripple its checks such as Rapidash, Rotom-S, and Articuno. Sludge Bomb lets Tangela threaten Grass-types such as Shiftry and Flapple, which take little from Tangela's other moves and are immune to Sleep Powder and Leech Seed. Synthesis is Tangela's most reliable recovery move, letting it more comfortably check Choice Band Sawk and Kangaskhan, but Leech Seed can be used as an alternative, providing recovery to Tangela and chipping down its checks. Sleep Powder lets Tangela neutralize a foe to make pivoting easier, whereas Toxic puts walls that can otherwise take advantage of Tangela, such as Miltank and Uxie, on a timer.

Tangela is a great choice for many teams, ranging from stall to bulky offense, and it appreciates being paired with special walls such as Galarian Stunfisk, Wishiwashi, and Clefairy. Partners such as Qwilfish, Cramorant, and Altaria can handle Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales for Tangela, while it can take on the likes of Kangaskhan and Rhydon for them. Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally-Poison and Miltank are appreciated to preserve Tangela's Eviolite. Entry hazard supports from the likes of Uxie, Piloswine, and Clefairy is appreciated by Tangela, as it can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from checks like Altaria, Frosmoth, and Rotom-S, which are pressured by Stealth Rock without their item. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Sawk, and Basculin value Tangela's ability to sponge hits for them when they are forced out.

Kangaskhan.comments:
Other Options

Body Slam is considerably weaker than Double-Edge, but Kangaskhan can use it instead for the paralysis chance and lack of recoil. Choice Band offers more immediate power and coverage, although the lack of reliable priority limits this set's potential. Substitute is an option to takes advantage of the switches Kangaskhan forces, and Power-Up Punch is another option for Kangaskhan to become a situational setup sweeper.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Poliwrath, Tangela, and Alolan Persian are able to take hits from Kangaskhan and threaten back with Fighting-type coverage, status, or pivoting. Tanks like Rhydon and Gurdurr also pose a threat to Kangaskhan.

Residual Damage: Kangaskhan's Fake Out is often punished by Rocky Helmet users like Miltank and Qwilfish. Furthermore, Kangaskhan's entry hazard vulnerability and induced recoil from Double-Edge causes it to lose valuable chunks of HP and limits its turns on the field.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers, especially ones able to take a Sucker Punch like Basculin, Silvally-Dark, and Choice Scarf Sawk are able to force out Kangaskhan. If Kangaskhan has an Adamant nature, more attackers like Rotom-S and Cramorant may also outspeed and deal with it.

sets.name: Priority Attacker
sets.description:
Kangaskhan is a dangerous priority attacker with wallbreaking potential when chaining together its STAB Fake Out and Double-Edge. It is thus equally prepared to check faster attackers like Basculin and Rotom and break special walls like Articuno and Clefairy. Sucker Punch combines with Fake Out for additional priority damage, and it is especially warranted to check setup sweepers like Silvally formes. Earthquake hits Steel- and Rock-types like Galarian Stunfisk, Coalossal, and Rhydon, and it avoids adverse contact effects from Rocky Helmet Qwilfish. Scrappy is essential to prevent frail Ghost-types from switching in and blocking Qwilfish's Intimidate. Silk Scarf improves Kangaskhan's main attacks. Heavy-Duty Boots instead combats Kangaskhan's residual damage vulnerability on teams with unreliable entry hazard control. A Jolly nature allows Kangaskhan to revenge kill Rotom-S and Choice Band Sawk more reliably, while Adamant picks up more KOs, like against Clefairy.

Entry hazards from Qwilfish, Coalossal, and Rhydon are invaluable to Kangaskhan, as it relies on the additional chip damage to stack with Fake Out and pressure more threats; Toxic Spikes from the first two is particularly potent. Another way to facilitate Fake Out is using defensive pivots such as Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Wishiwashi; these teammates are also valuable switch-ins when Kangaskhan is targeted by Sawk, Silvally formes, and Basculin. In return, these pivots rely on Kangaskhan to break walls that they are outstalled by and to punish threats like Frosmoth. Special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Basculin, Nasty Plot Skuntank, and Rotom break walls like Tangela and Rhydon that Kangaskhan struggles with. Fake Out and Sucker Punch won't deal with every faster threat, so a Choice Scarf user like Sawk or Rotom should clean and revenge kill alongside Kangaskhan. Knock Off support from Clefairy, Gurdurr, and Shiftry removes Heavy-Duty Boots, Eviolite, and Leftovers from walls, making Kangaskhan more effective at wallbreaking Altaria, Tangela, and Wishiwashi.

Jynx.comments:
Other Options

Substitute with Nasty Plot over Lovely Kiss is an option to avoid possible misses or status moves from passive Pokemon. However, it's not as powerful as putting an opposing Pokemon to sleep, and it still leaves Jynx vulnerable to Klinklang's Gear Grind and Cinccino's Tail Slap. Choice Scarf can be run over Choice Specs to get surprise KOs on faster Pokemon like Morpeko and Alolan Persian, however the difference in power is noticeable, and Jynx's entry hazard weakness gives it limited opportunities to revenge kill.

Checks and Counters

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Articuno, Wishiwashi, and Uxie can survive hits from Jynx and threaten it with Knock Off or U-turn. However, they need to be careful of Psyshock and Trick or they can eventually get in range of a KO during the course of a game if they lack reliable recovery.

Priority Users: Kangaskhan, Thwackey, Shiftry, and Gurdurr can exploit Jynx's physical frailty to KO or heavily damage it.

Steel-types: Klinklang and Perrserker can switch into Jynx safely if it locks itself into either of its STAB attacks, but they must be wary of Focus Blast.

Faster Pokemon: Alolan Persian, Rapidash, and Morpeko outspeed Jynx and OHKO it; they can also switch in against it on a good prediction. Cinccino and Manectric can always revenge kill Jynx, but they can never switch into it. Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom can always revenge kill Jynx, although Rotom can't KO it from full HP.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Jynx's good Speed tier and phenomenal STAB combination make it one of the most powerful special attackers in ZU. Choice Specs enables Jynx to OHKO common metagame picks like Tangela, Qwilfish, and Rotom and 2HKO Skuntank and physically defensive Alcremie. Psyshock can be used over Psychic to help against specially defensive foes such as Articuno and Wishiwashi. Focus Blast can OHKO Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker while also threatening Ice-resistant foes like Piloswine and Miltank. Trick cripples special walls like Clefairy and Articuno and make them ineffective. Dry Skin gives Jynx switch-in opportunities against Water-types such as Basculin and Qwilfish, although it must be wary of switching into the occasional Poison Jab from the latter.

Jynx appreciates teammates such as Thwackey and Silvally-Poison, which can bring it in safely and lure foes like Qwilfish, Altaria, and Tangela for it to take advantage of. Slow bulky pivots like Clefairy and Wishiwashi also allow it to switch in safely. Entry hazard control is key to Jynx's longevity, so Altaria, Articuno, Rotom, Morpeko, and Kabutops are good partners; most of the aforementioned Pokemon can also use a pivot move to bring Jynx in. Jynx's abysmal physical bulk and common weaknesses mean it requires bulky teammates, especially Knock Off and U-turn absorbers such as Alcremie, Clefairy, Silvally-Poison, and Tangela, to sponge physical hits.

sets.name: Lovely Kiss
sets.description:
Lovely Kiss and a good Speed tier allow Jynx to put an opposing Pokemon to sleep, possibly a defensive wall like Clefairy or Articuno that is expecting Choice Specs Jynx, in the early-game. Once its counter has been put to sleep, Jynx can threaten the rest of the team with its very good coverage. Moreover, Heavy-Duty Boots improves its longevity, allowing it to keep threatening KOs or put a foe to sleep. Nasty Plot is an option to improve Jynx's damage output, exploiting the free turns gained by putting a foe to sleep; however, it is not easy for Jynx to sweep the opposing team even with Nasty Plot, especially considering that Pokemon like Rapidash, Morpeko, and Alolan Persian can switch in on a predicted Nasty Plot and force it out.

Pivots like Thwackey, Silvally-Poison, Alolan Persian, and Basculin allow Jynx to safely get on the field in a favorable position and give it opportunities to use Lovely Kiss or to fire off a strong STAB move. The same applies to bulky pivots like Clefairy and Wishiwashi. Jynx's sleep support is beneficial for teammates like Klinklang, Perrserker, and Rapidash, which can take advantage of the free turns and force out common sleep fodder like Clefairy or Articuno. Jynx needs teammates that cover its weaknesses and can switch into fast Dark-types, so Alcremie and Gurdurr are good partners. Defensive Pokemon like Tangela and Qwilfish stop many priority users and fast physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Cinccino.

Articuno.comments:
Other Options

Articuno can opt for a physically offensive set with options like Triple Axel, Brave Bird, and Ice Shard, but physical walls are more common, which makes special Articuno more effective at breaking through defensive cores.

Checks and Counters

Rock-type Pokemon and Coverage: Due to its 4x weakness to Rock, any Rock-type move will at least 2HKO Articuno. This makes Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal extremely annoying for Articuno, as they can easily set up entry hazards against it.

Item Removal: Retaining Heavy-Duty Boots is key to maintaining Articuno's defensive capabilities, and it should avoid switching into Knock Off and Trick users like Shiftry, Gurdurr, Thwackey, and Rotom. However, if Articuno is the team's entry hazard remover and is able to consistently use Defog against the opposing Stealth Rock setter, it can afford to lose its item.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash force out Articuno with their super effective STAB move. However, they take great damage from Articuno's Flying-type STAB moves, and they dislike being crippled by Toxic.

Electric-types: Morpeko, Manectric, and Rotom formes threaten Articuno with their super effective STAB moves and generate momentum with Volt Switch. However, weaker Electric-types like Choice Scarf Rotom and defensive Rotom-S can't break through specially defensive Articuno.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Perrserker and Klinklang are immune to Toxic, resist Articuno's STAB moves, and take on Articuno with their super effective STAB moves.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Articuno is an amazing special wall and one of the best form of entry hazard control in ZU thanks to Pressure + Defog keeping entry hazards off the field against numerous setters such as Qwilfish, Uxie, and Clefairy, its amazing bulk, and reliable recovery in Roost. Freeze-Dry lets Articuno threaten entry hazard setters like Qwilfish and Stunfisk, as well as Pokemon that can freely switch into its other moves like Tangela and Altaria. Alternatively, Brave Bird is the preferred STAB move to check Frosmoth. Toxic wears down opposing walls such as Cramorant and entry hazard setters such as Coalossal and Rhydon, which forces Articuno out, while U-turn turns Articuno into a pivot. Articuno can also run Haze to stop Stored Power users like Alcremie and Uxie or Heal Bell to act as a cleric. The given EV spread lets Articuno outspeed Adamant Trevenant. Alternatively, Articuno can run 136 Speed EVs with a Jolly nature to outspeed Flapple and Adamant Shiftry.

Specially defensive Articuno fits on almost any kind of team, ranging from stall to bulky offense. On offensive teams, it forms a VoltTurn core with partners like Silvally formes, Uxie, and Alolan Persian. Frail attackers such as Basculin, Cinccino, and Shiftry enjoy safely coming on the field through these VoltTurn cores and benefit from slower pivots like Articuno sponging attacks for them. Knock Off absorbers like Qwilfish, Pyukumuku, and Silvally formes are great partners that can preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots and sponge physical hits, while it handles special attackers for them. Ground-types like Rhydon and Stunfisk make for excellent partners for their ability to handle Articuno's weaknesses, while they appreciate Articuno checking Frosmoth and specially offensive Basculin.

sets.name: SubRoost
sets.description:
The combination of Substitute, Roost, and Pressure lets Articuno stall out moves with low PP such as Ninetales's Fire Blast, Kabutop's Stone Edge, and Gourgeist-S's Poltergeist. Thanks to its great Speed and bulk, Articuno is able to easily set up a Substitute against passive Pokemon such as Tangela, Eldegoss, and Qwilfish. Toxic works well with the combination of Roost + Substitute, racking up damage on foes like Coalossal, Uxie, and Kangaskhan. Freeze-Dry is the preferred STAB move to cover Qwilfish, Wishiwashi, and Altaria, which can sponge Toxic.

SubRoost Articuno fits well on balance and bulky offense teams looking for a Pokemon that does well against balance teams. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian are appreciated to preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots. VoltTurn users like Basculin, Manectric, and Uxie safely bring Articuno onto the field, letting it avoid Knock Off from the likes of Tangela and Uxie. Ground-types such as Alolan Dugtrio, Rhydon, and Stunfisk make for great partners, checking Steel-, Fire-, Rock-, and Ground-types such as Perrserker, Coalossal, and Rhydon. In return, Articuno checks Water- and Grass-types such as Qwilfish, Appletun, and Flapple for them. Checks to Steel-types like Sawk, Rapidash, and Manectric are especially important, since Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker completely shut down SubRoost Articuno.

sets.name: Roost + 3 Attacks
sets.description:
Articuno is a great offensive pivot that is able to dish out powerful Hurricanes and Freeze-Drys. The given EV investment in conjunction with its coverage allows Articuno to outspeed and nail threats such as Thwackey, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr. Thanks to U-turn, Articuno is able to pivot from bad matchups and safely bring in partners.

Roost + 3 Attacks Articuno fits on offensive teams with VoltTurn cores, which makes Uxie, Rotom, and Wishiwashi great partners. Articuno also excels on entry hazard stacking teams, since it preys on common Defoggers such as Cramorant and Altaria and is able to generate momentum with U-turn. Physical wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Silvally formes can take advantage of Articuno inviting in and pivoting against special walls such as Coalossal, Clefairy, and Miltank. In return, Articuno can threaten physical walls such as Qwilfish, Wishiwashi, and Tangela for them. Ground-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Rhydon are great partners, checking Rock-, Fire-, Steel-, and Electric-types such as Coalossal, Klinklang, and Stunfisk. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish let Articuno keep its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Qwilfish.comments:
Other Options

A Swords Dance set can act as a terrifying stallbreaker with Qwilfish's Toxic immunity and access to Taunt. However, it lacks bulk and power, even when boosted. Qwilfish can run max Speed on its defensive set to outspeed attackers like Skuntank and Adamant Kangaskhan; however, that jeopardizes its ability to handle physical attackers. Such sets can run Destiny Bond to get an unexpected KO, but Qwilfish usually doesn't have the room for it and is required to run an inferior max Speed spread. Although weaker than Liquidation, Waterfall is an option on both sets for its flinch chance and synergy with Thunder Wave. Poison Jab is also an alternative to the STAB moves on defensive sets for its ability to damage Water-resistant attackers like Exeggutor, Basculin, and Shiftry and spread poison. However, Thunder Wave and Scald already spread status and cripple those Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Uxie: Thanks to Levitate, Uxie isn't affected by Qwilfish's entry hazards and can heavily damage it with Psychic, while Qwilfish hardly hurts Uxie with its moves. Uxie's Future Sight is also a huge threat to Qwilfish, as it prevents Qwilfish from switching into threats it is supposed to counter, such as Rapidash and Gurdurr.

Ground-immune Entry Hazard Removers: Entry hazard removers such as Rotom, Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cryogonal aren't affected by Spikes and threaten Qwilfish with their powerful special attacks. They can easily force Qwilfish out and use that opportunity to remove its entry hazards.

Special Attackers: Qwilfish's special bulk is underwhelming, meaning that special attackers such as Thievul, Rotom, and Articuno can easily OHKO it.

Ground-types: Qwilfish is weak to Ground-types and cannot handle crucial physical attackers such as Rhydon and Piloswine, even if they are 2HKOed by Qwilfish's Water-type STAB moves. Qwilfish also takes heavy damage from common Ground-type coverage from wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; the latter is noteworthy due to Inner Focus ignoring Intimidate.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Even with Intimidate, Qwilfish's bulk isn't amazing and, without any reliable recovery moves, it is quickly put in range of powerful wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Choice Band Cinccino, and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

sets.name: Defensive Spikes
sets.description:
Qwilfish is a premier physical wall that is able to set Spikes or Toxic Spikes and counter powerful physical attackers such as Basculin and Sawk. Its typing also lets it absorb Toxic Spikes from opposing Qwilfish. Thanks to Taunt, Qwilfish can prevent slower Pok√©mon such as Pyukumuku and Gurdurr from setting up, recovering HP, and setting entry hazards. Thunder Wave cripples faster attackers such as Skuntank, specially offensive Basculin, and Articuno, which can otherwise freely switch into Qwilfish. Liquidation is the preferred STAB move for its ability to OHKO Rapidash and Ninetales after minimal residual damage. Scald is another option that, while significantly weaker, can cripple switch-ins with a burn. Pain Split improves Qwilfish's longevity versus bulkier teams. Rocky Helmet lets Qwilfish wear down physical attackers, punishing resisted moves like Gurdurr's Mach Punch, Sawk's Close Combat, and Basculin's Flip Turn. Alternatively, Black Sludge makes Qwilfish less reliant on Pain Split. The given EV spread lets Qwilfish outspeed Timid Exeggutor and maximize its physical bulk.

Qwilfish fits well on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its defensive utility and ability to set entry hazards. Special walls like Articuno, Stunfisk, and Clefairy make for great partners, as they are able to handle special attackers like Frosmoth, Rotom, and Manectric; in return, Qwilfish handles physical attackers such as Sawk and Rapidash. Ground-immune and -resistant Pokemon such as Rotom-S, Uxie, and Tangela cover Qwilfish's Ground weakness. VoltTurn cores pair well with Spikes, as they force a lot of switches. Therefore, Pokemon such as Rotom, Silvally-Dark, and Cinccino make for great partners. Spikes are appreciated by wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; Kangaskhan is a noteworthy example, as it can force switches thanks to Fake Out. Knock Off users such as Shiftry, Thwackey, and Gurdurr can remove opposing Heavy-Duty Boots, bolstering the effectiveness of Qwilfish's entry hazards.

Piloswine.comments:
Other Options

Toxic allows Piloswine to wear down foes like Tangela, Poliwrath, Pyukumuku, and Wishiwashi. Rock Slide provides coverage against Frosmoth and Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Poliwrath, Wishiwashi, Pyukumuku, and Cramorant are able to switch into Piloswine and force it out, with Cramorant also removing Stealth Rock. Although they cannot directly switch into Piloswine, offensive Water-types like Basculin and Ludicolo can threaten to KO it.

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath pressure Piloswine immensely.

Grass-types: Even though they cannot switch into Piloswine and fear being revenge killed by Ice Shard if weakened, Shiftry and Tangela are able to threaten Piloswine. Tangela is able to tank hits from Piloswine and cripple it with Toxic and Knock Off or KO it with Leaf Storm or Giga Drain.

Residual Damage: Given Piloswine's lack of recovery, residual damage from entry hazards and status can wear it down over the course of the battle.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Piloswine's typing, huge bulk, and Thick Fat let it serve as a Stealth Rock setter that has good matchups against some Stealth Rock setters such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk. Earthquake and Icicle Crash form a formidable STAB combination, hitting relevant targets such as Skuntank, Silvally formes, and Rotom-S. Ice Shard allows Piloswine to revenge kill weakened foes such as Shiftry and Rotom. Thick Fat lets Piloswine switch into the likes of Rapidash.

Piloswine fits best on bulky offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take hits and consistently set Stealth Rock. Water-types such as Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant are problematic for Piloswine; checks to them such as Eldegoss and Cramorant are appreciated. Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and the aforementioned Poliwrath greatly pressure Piloswine. Partners such as Rotom-S and Qwilfish can alleviate this weakness; the former can provide VoltTurn support, while the latter can wear down problematic foes such as Tangela and Miltank with Spikes and Toxic Spikes.

Miltank.comments:
Other Options

With its great Speed tier, useable Attack stat, and decent coverage, Miltank can also run offensive sets, while keeping defensive utilities with its abilities. However, it faces heavy competition from other Normal-type wallbreakers like Cinccino, Silvally, and Kangaskhan, and it heavily struggles due to its inability to threaten Rotom.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Thanks to their super effective STAB moves, the likes of Sawk, Poliwrath, and Throh can easily defeat Miltank. Pokemon like Perrserker and Jynx also carry Fighting-type coverage, allowing them to break through Miltank.

Toxic: Toxic heavily cripples Miltank, tremendously limiting its ability to handle most threats in the long run. However, it can combat this weakness with Heal Bell.

Toxic Counterplay: Miltank mostly relies on Toxic to deal damage. However, Pokemon like Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom, Nasty Plot Skuntank, and Rest Alcremie can set up on Miltank without fearing Toxic much, proceeding to break through its team. Altaria and Clefairy aren't much bothered by Toxic, reliably heal off Seismic Toss damage, and take advantage of Miltank with their own status moves. Rest users like Throh and Wishiwashi can also absorb Toxic and avoid the 3HKO from Seismic Toss, threatening Miltank with their powerful moves.

Trick: Rotom, Manectric, and Jynx can cripple Miltank and limit its walling capabilities with Trick. However, the latter may struggle to switch directly in against Body Slam variants.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Specially defensive Miltank can take advantage of most special attackers like Articuno, Tangela, and Alcremie. Seismic Toss is its most consistent attack, ignoring stat boosts and bothering even defensive behemoths like Tangela and Articuno. While often weaker, Body Slam is alternative that can spread paralysis. Toxic allows Miltank to cripple foes like Stunfisk and Eldegoss, forcing certain walls such as Wishiwashi and Altaria to use Rest or switch out to activate Natural Cure, respectively. If Miltank's team already has a Stealth Rock user, Miltank can run Heal Bell to help teammates like Silvally formes and Thwackey, which can end up crippled by the likes of paralysis or a Scald burn. Thick Fat allows Miltank to take on threatening special wallbreakers like Ninetales and Frosmoth. The given EV spread lets Miltank outspeed Timid Frosmoth while maximizing its special bulk.

Specially defensive Miltank is a great pick for balance teams. It has great synergy with Grass-types like Eldegoss, Tangela, and Gourgeist formes, being able to handle most of their checks, while they help with physical attackers like Thwackey and Sawk. Offensive Ground-types such as Alolan Dugtrio, Rhydon, and Piloswine help Miltank take on special attackers like Skuntank and prevent Electric-types such as Manectric and Rotom from freely pivoting. Gourgeist formes, Alcremie, and Altaria are also appreciated to answer Fighting-types like Sawk and Gurdurr, and in exchange they appreciate Miltank's Ice resistance and ability to handle special attackers. Due to Miltank's susceptibility to status, status absorbers like physically defensive Wishiwashi and Altaria make for great partners.

sets.name: Mixed Wall
sets.description:
With a mixed defensive EV spread, Miltank can take on most unboosted attackers in the tier, whether special or even physical like Rhydon lacking Swords Dance, Alolan Dugtrio, and Liepard. Seismic Toss's fixed damage is very reliable, while Body Slam, if often weaker, can spread paralysis while keeping enough power for frail attackers. Toxic lets Miltank put foes with recovery like Eldegoss, Tangela, and Articuno on a timer, allowing it to win one-on-one. Toxic can also force Pokemon like Wishiwashi, Throh, and Alcremie to use Rest later on. Heal Bell is an option for teams that already have a Stealth Rock user, helping its team against bulkier teams using a lot of status moves. Heavy-Duty Boots maximizes Miltank's longevity, giving it more switch-in opportunities; however, Rocky Helmet is an option to punish physical attackers, especially U-turn users like Cinccino, Thwackey, and Silvally formes. Thick Fat is the preferred ability, letting Miltank handle Rapidash and Frosmoth. The given spread allows Miltank to outspeed Timid Frosmoth and avoid the 2HKO from Nasty Plot-boosted Ninetales, as well as checking physical attackers like Swords Dance Thwackey, Kangaskhan, and Silvally-Dark.

This set fits well in balance teams looking for a blanket wall. It pairs especially well with Fighting-type checks such as Alcremie, Altaria, Cramorant, and Gourgeist-S able to answer Poliwrath and Sawk. Specially defensive Ground-types such as Rhydon and Stunfisk are great to answer Rotom and Skuntank for Miltank, while Miltank takes care of Ice-types like Jynx and Frosmoth. Status absorbers like Throh and specially defensive Wishiwashi can take on Toxic users like Altaria, Alolan Persian, and Stunfisk for Miltank.

sets.name: Nascar Cow
sets.description:
With its great bulk, even with only HP investment, and excellent Speed, outpacing major threats like Silvally formes, Sawk, and Thievul, Miltank can double up as a wall and revenge killer for bulkier teams. Seismic Toss is the prefered offensive move thanks to its fixed damage; Body Slam's paralysis chance is not very valuable due to Miltank already outspeeding most foes. Toxic puts threats with reliable recovery like Alcremie, Articuno, and Cramorant on a timer. This set can notably hit Rotom with Toxic before it sets up a Substitute. If Miltank doesn't need to set up Stealth Rock, Heal Bell turns it into a cleric. Rocky Helmet is the preferred item, as, paired with Miltank's fast Seismic Toss and Toxic damage, it enables huge damage on physical attackers. Sap Sipper turns Miltank into one of the most reliable Grass-type checks in the tier, absorbing Sleep Powder from Eldegoss and Tangela, not carrying that much about losing its item from Thwackey's and Tangela's Knock Off, and being immune to both of Gourgeist-S's STAB moves. Thick Fat is another option, but due to this set's lack of Special Defense investment, it can't reliably switch into the likes of Frosmoth, Jynx, and Ninetales.

This fast Miltank set fits extremely well in bulkier teams with few other fast Pokemon. Its partner in crime is Stunfisk, as it can handle special attackers, especially Rotom and Skuntank, for Miltank. In return, Miltank provides Heal Bell support, helping Stunfisk combat Defoggers like Altaria, Rotom, and Articuno. It also hard walls Grass-types, which are the main counters to Stunfisk. Fighting-type checks such as Alcremie and Cramorant are also much appreciated to handle the likes of Poliwrath, Sawk, and Gurdurr. Even with Heal Bell, Miltank struggles in the long term versus Toxic, so Toxic absorbers like Klinklang, Wishiwashi, and Throh make for good partners. Wishiwashi is noteworthy, as are other Grass-weak Pokemon such as Rhydon and Basculin, because Miltank hard walls their main answers.

Shiftry.comments:
Other Options

Swords Dance variants can run Leaf Blade over Leaf Storm to have a more consistent Grass STAB move to clean, better dealing with walls such as Poliwrath and Carbink. However, Leaf Blade is worse at wallbreaking in the early- and mid-game because it lacks raw power and relies on Swords Dance.

Checks and Counters

Colbur Berry: Thanks to Colbur Berry, Uxie and Cofagrigus can stomach a boosted Knock Off from Shiftry and OHKO it back with U-turn and Body Press respectively.

Dark-resistant Pokemon: Dark-resistant foes such as Silvally-Dark, Gurdurr, and Alcremie can comfortably take Shiftry's Knock Off and OHKO Shiftry with their super effective moves. However, most of these Pokemon have to watch out for Shiftry's less spammable Leaf Storm, which can heavily damage them, and are obliterated by a boosted Solar Blade.

U-turn: Shiftry's 4x weakness to Bug makes it extremely susceptible to common U-turn users such as Silvally-Dark, Liepard, and Cinccino.

Faster Attackers: While Shiftry's Sucker Punch is very powerful and able to easily clean teams after a single Swords Dance, it is not strong enough to threaten faster Pokemon when unboosted. Therefore, faster attackers such as Silvally-Poison, Articuno, and Rotom-S can force Shiftry out.

Priority Moves: While Shiftry resists Thwackey's Grassy Glide and opposing Shiftry's Sucker Punch, it takes heavy damage from other priority moves such as Kangaskhan's Fake Out, which can pick off a very weakened Shiftry in sun. Piloswine's Ice Shard and Gurdurr's Mach Punch are noteworthy, as they need significantly less chip damage to take out Shiftry.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
Shiftry is a powerful mixed attacker and stallbreaker thanks to its amazing offensive typing letting it threaten common walls such as Uxie, Wishiwashi, and Cofagrigus. Sucker Punch lets Shiftry pick off faster attackers that have been weakened, such as Rotom, Cinccino, and Basculin. Leaf Storm acts as a powerful special nuke, heavily damaging physical walls such as Qwilfish, Gurdurr, and Cofagrigus. Swords Dance lets Shiftry act as a late-game cleaner by empowering its Sucker Punch and also lets it wallbreak more easily with Knock Off, OHKOing Altaria that have been weakened after a Swords Dance. Defog is an alternative if the team lacks a Defogger and takes advantage of Shiftry's good matchup against common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Uxie.

Shiftry is a good pick for any offensive team looking for a strong wallbreaker with a great stall matchup. Qwilfish is an amazing partners that punishes U-turn with Rocky Helmet; in return, Shiftry improves the effectiveness of its Spikes by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Rapidash with Knock Off. Other physical wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Sawk, and Cinccino appreciate Shiftry weakening physical walls such as Tangela with the combination of Knock Off and Leaf Storm. Shiftry also appreciate VoltTurn support from users such as Basculin, Uxie, and Rotom, which can safely bring it onto the field. Faster threats that resist Sucker Punch, like Sawk and Alolan Persian, are able to consistently force out Shiftry; therefore, checks to them like Rotom-S and Poliwrath are appreciated.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Shiftry is a powerhouse in sun, outspeeding the whole unboosted metagame and most Choice Scarf users. Shiftry's deadly STAB combination lets it OHKO most Pokemon it outspeeds, and it can easily break through defensive teams after a Swords Dance or Growth. Sucker Punch lets Shiftry revenge kill faster attackers when sun is not up. Sun-boosted Heat Wave lets Shiftry OHKO strong physical walls that can take its other moves, such as Shiinotic and Tangela, as well as OHKO Abomasnow.

Shiftry is a staple on sun teams due to it raw power and lack of offensive and defensive checks under sun. Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor make for great partners that enables Shiftry to wallbreak or sweep. The former two can even safely bring Shiftry onto the field with U-turn. Other Chlorophyll users such as Exeggutor can also take advantage of sun and form a Grass spam core with Shiftry, weakening each other's checks. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash can also utilize sun to boost their STAB moves and weaken Shiftry's checks like opposing Fire-types, Piloswine, and Gurdurr.

Manectric.comments:
Other Options

Toxic is an option to cripple counters like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Appletun without getting rid of its Choice item with Switcheroo. However, Switcheroo is more consistent, as being locked on Toxic can invite threats in. Manectric can run a Heavy-Duty Boots set with Toxic over Switcheroo; however, it lacks the power of Choice Specs and Speed of Choice Scarf, making it hard to justify.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types like Stunfisk, Rhydon, and Piloswine are immune to Manectric's STAB moves and OHKO it. However, Galarian Stunfisk have to watch out for Choice Specs-boosted Fire-type coverage, while Rhydon and Piloswine dislike getting their Eviolite removed by Switcheroo.

Special Walls: Special walls like Eldegoss and Clefairy are able to sponge Manectric's hits, and the former two can even nullify the chip damage from Volt Switch with Regenerator. Appletun, in particular, resists every move from Manectric and mitigates damage with Recover. However, they dislike losing their items to Switcheroo.

Priority Users: Due to Manectric's lackluster bulk, it gets easily removed by priority users such as Choice Band Thwackey, Kangaskhan, and Shiftry after chip damage.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Manectric is a potent Choice Scarf user thanks to its high Speed letting it outspeed sweepers like +1 Silvally formes and Choice Scarf Sawk, great Electric + Fire coverage, and Volt Switch. Additionally, it brings a valuable Electric immunity thanks to Lightning Rod letting it absorb Volt Switch from Rotom formes. Overheat provides coverage for Electric-resistant foes like Eldegoss, Galarian Stunfisk, and Tangela. If Manectric's high Speed tier isn't needed anymore, it can use Switcheroo to cripple special walls such as Stunfisk, Clefairy, and Rhydon.

Manectric is a great choice for VoltTurn teams looking for a revenge killer and Electric immunity. Additional VoltTurn users such as Uxie, Articuno, Wishiwashi, and Alolan Persian are appreciated. The aforementioned ones are especially great, as they can sponge hits for Manectric, making up for its lackluster bulk, and wear down Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine. Physical wallbreakers like Basculin, Kangaskhan, and Sawk can take advantage of special walls that Manectric forces in and pivots against with Volt Switch. Entry hazard support from partners like Rhydon, Coalossal, and Qwilfish benefits Manectric by letting it take more advantage of Volt Switch and guaranteeing OHKOs against Tangela.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Manectric is a powerful Choice Specs user thanks to its great offensive stats and Electric + Fire coverage, which let it threaten common defensive cores like Articuno + Qwilfish + Galarian Stunfisk. Choice Specs-boosted Volt Switch whittles down special walls like Clefairy, Throh, and Appletun while retaining momentum. Overheat allows Manectric to OHKO threats like Flapple and Rotom and break down Ground-types such as Galarian Stunfisk. Flamethrower is an alternative that doesn't drop Manectric's Special Attack, which makes it more spammable, but it does not break down Volt Switch switch-ins as effectively as Overheat. Switcheroo lets Manectric cripple checks like Eldegoss, Piloswine, and Rhydon, which it is unable to break through, at the cost giving up Choice Specs.

Manectric fits at best on VoltTurn cores with partners like Basculin, Articuno, and Uxie, chipping down the opposing team through constant pivoting. Spikes support from Qwilfish or Coalossal helps this process by further weakening the foes, putting foes like Sawk and Flapple into OHKO range. Physical wallbreakers like Sawk, Thwackey, and Shiftry can take advantange of special walls and Ground-types that Manectric forces in and benefit from its ability to safely bring them in. Special cleaners like Choice Scarf Basculin, Nasty Plot Liepard, and Frosmoth enjoy Manectric weakening special walls, making it easier for them to clean late-game.

Altaria.comments:
Other Options

The combination of Fire Spin and Perish Song lets Altaria trap and take out walls such as Musharna and Pyukumuku; however, this set lacks the utility of Defog and only traps a limited number of Pokemon. Draco Meteor is Altaria's strongest move, but it is less consistent than Hurricane and Dual Wingbeat due to the Special Attack drop. Heal Bell can be used on stall teams lacking a cleric.

Checks and Counters

Ice-types and Ice-type Coverage: Altaria's 4x weakness to Ice makes it extremely vulnerable to any Ice-type attacks. Altaria is threatened by Ice-types such as Abomasnow, Frosmoth, and Jynx, but it also has to watch out for Ice coverage from attackers such as Basculin and Poliwrath.

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Kabutops and Rhydon threaten Altaria with Stone Edge and can safely set up Stealth Rock versus Altaria.

Dragon-types: Due to its weakness to Dragon, powerful Dragon-type wallbreakers like Flapple and Appletun can break through Altaria with their STAB moves, even if they can't switch into Altaria's Hurricane.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Clefairy and Alcremie pressure Altaria with their super effective STAB move, and they aren't pressured by Toxic thanks to Magic Guard and Aromatherapy, respectively. They can even take advantage of Altaria to set up with Calm Mind.

Setup Sweepers: While Altaria's bulk is great, it gets easily overwhelmed by strong attackers that can set up such as Silvally-Dark, Rotom-S, and Shiftry.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Altaria is a premier wall in ZU thanks to its ability to reliably answer powerful physical and special attackers such as Thwackey, Ninetales, Tangela, and Sawk. Toxic allows Altaria to put foes on a timer, letting it comfortably use Defog against entry hazard setters such as Piloswine and Miltank. Hurricane is Altaria's strongest STAB move, letting it threaten foes such as Qwilfish, Gurdurr, and Thwackey. Earthquake is an alternative that targets Toxic-immune foes such as Skuntank and Perrserker, while allowing Altaria to take on Fire-types more easily. The given EV spread allows Altaria to outspeed Adamant Perrserker and avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Thievul while maximizing its physical bulk.

Altaria is an excellent pick for balance and stall teams looking for a Defogger and a check to Fire-types. Offensive Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales can take advantage of Altaria's checks such as Clefairy, Rhydon, and Frosmoth while benefitting from Altaria walling opposing Fire- and Water-types. These two are also checks to Ice-types, and additional checks such as Piloswine, Poliwrath, and Miltank make for great partners, handling Altaria's biggest weakness. Other walls such as Pyukumuku, Rhydon, and Wishiwashi appreciate Altaria's ability to absorb status for them; in return, they can handle threats that Altaria struggles with such as Jynx and Flapple. Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Rotom can revenge kill the threats that can muscle through Altaria.

Skuntank.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb provides additional damage output, but the recoil damage limits Skuntank's longevity and makes it prone to entry hazards. Defog and Heavy-Duty Boots turn Skuntank into an offensive entry hazard remover, but this makes it inconsistent in its stallbreaking role.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to take a boosted hit from Skuntank and OHKO it back with their STAB moves.

Faster Offensive Threats: Skuntank's mediocre Speed leaves it susceptible to faster attackers such as Rapidash, Kangskhan, and Cinccino. Special wallbreakers and pivots like Rotom and Basculin can also threaten to revenge kill Skuntank, preventing it from consistently performing its role. However, physical attackers should be wary of residual damage from Aftermath.

Special Walls: Although they do not appreciate Taunt and being poisoned by Sludge Bomb, special walls such as Wishiwashi and Type: Null are able to take boosted hits from Skuntank and pivot with U-turn, safely bringing in revenge killers to threaten it. Galarian Stunfisk is able to wear down Skuntank if it lacks Fire Blast.

sets.name: Stallbreaker
sets.description:
Skuntank is a great stallbreaker in ZU; its Poison / Dark typing gives it various opportunities to set up against foes such as Uxie and Tangela. While initially weak, Skuntank can pummel passive walls like Clefairy and Cofagrigus with Nasty Plot and its STAB coverage. Taunt can be used to prevent foes like Miltank and Pyukumuku from recovering HP and setup sweepers like Quiver Dance Frosmoth from setting up. Alternatively, Fire Blast helps Skuntank better break through Frosmoth and 2HKOes Galarian Stunfisk after a Nasty Plot boost.

Skuntank fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its Toxic and Psychic immunities, stallbreaking, and ability to pressure Ghost-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types like Cofagrigus, Uxie, and Clefairy. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to heavily pressure Skuntank; checks to them such as Basculin and Cramorant are appreciated. The aforementioned Water-types can also lure in Grass-types like Eldegoss and Tangela for Skuntank to take advantage of. Partners like Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes benefit from Skuntank weakening foes such as Tangela, Qwilfish, and Alcremie to clean late-game.

Spiritomb.comments:
Other Options

Spiritomb can run a physical wallbreaker set with Choice Band thanks to powerful moves in Poltergeist and Sucker Punch. Choice Band also pairs well with Trick, as it lets Spiritomb cripple the few Pokemon that can safely switch into Poltergeist such as Miltank and Tangela. However, Spiritomb is too slow to be a real offensive threat and being Choice-locked into Sucker Punch makes it very exploitable.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Shiftry, Skuntank, and Silvally-Dark resist Spiritomb's Dark Pulse and use it as setup fodder or, in Alolan Persian's case, beat it with the combination of Taunt + Toxic.

Wallbreakers: With no way of boosting its average physical bulk and Rest as its only form of recovery, Spiritomb gets overpowered by strong physical wallbreakers such as Flapple, Basculin, and Silvally formes. Spiritomb's special bulk is also lackluster before setting up a Calm Mind, and it can be forced out by special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Rotom and Basculin.

Alcremie: Alcremie is able to use Spiritomb as setup fodder for its Calm Mind sets and defeat it with Dazzling Gleam, while it is unable to do much in return. It should, however, be noted that mono-attacking variants of Alcremie running Stored Power get PP stalled by Spiritomb.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Spiritomb is a fearsome defensive Calm Mind sweeper that is able to find setup opportunities against some threats like Sawk locked into Close Combat, Swoobat, and Cofagrigus. Dark Pulse is the preferred STAB move, as, unlike Shadow Ball, it has no immunities. Rest is Spiritomb's most reliable recovery move and lets it get rid of status. Sleep Talk prevents Spritomb from being completely passive during Rest. Pressure lets Spiritomb PP stall defensive walls like Throh and Clefairy.

Spiritomb fits best on stall teams where its initial passivity isn't as crippling, and its unique defensive utility and PP stalling capabilities are appreciated. On these teams, Spiritomb's teammates whittle down and remove its counters over the course of a match, so it can be used as a late-game wincon. Physical walls like Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria handle powerful wallbreakers such as Basculin and Silvally formes. Special walls like Clefairy and Eldegoss are necessary to handle special wallbreakers such as Ninetales and Basculin, which can force out an unboosted Spiritomb. Some of them even provide Heal Bell support to wake up Spiritomb after it uses Rest. Checks to Dark-types like Alcremie, Mawile, and Throh are appreciated for their ability to take on foes such as Skuntank and Shiftry, which use Spiritomb as setup fodder. Checks to Alcremie such as Pyukumuku and Haze Articuno are also necessary, as it is a major threat to stall teams and can freely come in on Spiritomb.

Leafeon.comments:
Other Options

Weather Ball targets physically defensive Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S, but they already do not appreciate taking a Knock Off or Double-Edge. Synthesis provides Leafeon with sun-boosted recovery and counteracts the residual damage from Life Orb.

Checks and Counters

Grass-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon such as Altaria, Gourgeist-XL, and Tangela resist Solar Blade and are able to pressure Leafeon with status. However, they dislike being crippled by Knock Off and weakened by Double-Edge.

Poison-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off or Double-Edge, Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skuntank are able to take unboosted hits from Leafeon and retaliate with their STAB moves.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Leafeon, although they must be wary of Knock Off and Double-Edge.

Residual Damage and Priority: Recoil from Life Orb and Double-Edge, as well as residual damage from entry hazards, limits Leafeon's survivability and makes it susceptible to being revenge killed by foes such as Kangaskhan and Piloswine.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Leafeon finds a niche on sun teams as a physical sweeper, utilizing its bulk to set up with Swords Dance and threaten foes with a Life Orb-boosted Solar Blade. Leaf Blade is a notable alternative over Solar Blade that, despite its lower damage output, provides a reliable STAB attack when sun is not up. Knock Off allows Leafeon to weaken Grass-resistant foes such as Ninetales, Tangela, and Silvally-Poison. Double-Edge gives Leafeon coverage against problematic foes like Skuntank, Altaria, and the aforementioned Ninetales and Silvally-Poison.

Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor are mandatory, as they enable Leafeon to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and let it utilize Solar Blade. Leafeon can form an attacking core with other sun sweepers such as Shiftry and Ivysaur, with all weakening each other's shared checks in Pokemon such as Skuntank. Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash can also take advantage of sun to boost their STAB moves and threaten foes such as Eldegoss and Tangela. Ground-types such as Piloswine and Rhydon can take advantage of Poison- and Fire-types that Leafeon invites in and use that opportunity to fire off a strong hit or set Stealth Rock; in return, they appreciate Leafeon threatening opposing Water-types like Wishiwashi and Basculin.

Rotom.comments:
Other Options

Toxic can be used over Will-O-Wisp to better cripple defensive walls like Eldegoss and Coalossal at the expense of not punishing physical attackers as hard. Discharge is an alternative to Thunderbolt on sets with Hex. Rotom can forgo Special Attack investment and run a more bulky set with maximum HP investment to better check physical Ground- and Fighting-types like Piloswine and Sawk.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Silvally-Dark and Alolan Persian are faster than non-Choice Scarf Rotom and can revenge kill it easily. Skuntank can use Rotom as setup fodder if it has locked itself into Shadow Ball. Shiftry and Morpeko resist Rotom's STAB attacks but must be wary of switching into Will-O-Wisp or being pivoted upon, as they are quite frail.

Electric-immune Pokemon: Rhydon, Piloswine, Stunfisk, and Manectric can safely switch into Rotom's Electric-type attacks, especially if it has a Choice item. However, Rhydon and Piloswine dislike Will-O-Wisp and Trick, and all of the aforementioned Pokemon do not enjoy switching into Choice Specs Shadow Ball.

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Despite Rotom having a decent Special Attack stat, it struggles to break past Pokemon with solid special bulk, as they can take a hit and retaliate. Frosmoth can set up relatively freely on Rotom as long as it avoids Trick, while Throh can threaten Rotom immediately with Knock Off. Specially defensive walls such as Clefairy, Appletun, and Malamar are great long-term checks, as they have reliable recovery; Clefairy can also pivot into a revenge killer, while the latter two threaten Rotom immediately.

Faster Threats: Non-Choice Scarf Rotom is very susceptible to being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Basculin. Faster Pokemon such as Rapidash, Cinccino, and Gourgeist-S threaten Rotom. Pokemon with priority moves such as Thwackey and Kangaskhan can also threaten to revenge kill Rotom after some prior chip damage.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf improves Rotom's revenge killing capabilities at the cost of some wallbreaking power; it outpaces foes like Cinccino, Silvally-Poison, and Choice Scarf Sawk. Volt Switch can be used to pick off weakened foes while also keeping momentum against potential switch-ins. Trick can be used once there isn't a need for Rotom's revenge killing purposes and punishes passive walls like Galarian Stunfisk and Articuno. Thunderbolt makes for a great cleaning move, as it is a stronger Electric-type STAB move that doesn't force Rotom out. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp cripples opposing targets, namely physical Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Galarian Stunfisk, while Defog is useful on teams that cannot fit entry hazard removal elsewhere.

Rotom enjoys the luxury of being able to use Volt Switch as often as possible, so having a entry hazard remover such as Articuno, Altaria, or Coalossal is a good idea. Pairing Rotom with Pokemon that can deal with Ground-types like Poliwrath and Gourgeist-S is also recommended to achieve this goal. Rotom also benefits greatly from entry hazard support, as it wants to use Volt Switch often to force out common Pokemon like Qwilfish and Articuno and wear down common switch-ins such as Throh and Audino. Good examples of entry hazard setters include Miltank, Qwilfish, and Rhydon. Physically offensive threats such as Sawk, Rapidash, and Silvally-Dark benefit from Rotom's ability to bring them in safely after forcing out their checks. Rotom is great on VoltTurn cores and works well with other pivots such as Articuno, Wishiwashi, and Thwackey.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
With great status moves and Volt Switch, Rotom is a great offensive pivot that offers solid utility. Defog is great on teams that need entry hazard control, while Pain Split provides Rotom with a form of recovery. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers and Ground-types such as Rhydon, Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Piloswine, and it also boosts the power of Hex. Colbur Berry prevents Rotom from being KOed by Sawk's Knock Off, which gives Rotom a chance to cripple it with a burn, while Heavy-Duty Boots allows Rotom to avoid taking Stealth Rock damage when pivoting. Sitrus Berry can be used for more general increased longevity and is preferred over Leftovers due to the constant pivoting.

Rotom is best used on bulky offense and balance teams that benefit from its ability to disrupt opposing teams and offer support with Defog. Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Sawk that appreciate Rotom's ability to bring them in safely; and in return, they can make up for Rotom's lack of immediate power, as it is reliant on spreading burns in order to maximize its power. Offensive threats such as Rapidash, Ninetales, and Skuntank appreciate Rotom's ability to lure in Ground-types and cripple them with burns. Rapidash and Ninetales also benefit from Defog and Rotom forcing out Water-types like Wishiwashi and Cramorant. Skuntank helps Rotom by checking faster Ghost-types such as Gourgeist-S and Choice Scarf Rotom and Dark-types like Shiftry and Thievul. Other status inducers like Thunder Wave Qwilfish and Toxic Rapidash pair well with Hex.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Rotom is one of the most threatening special attackers in ZU due to the lack of Pokemon that resist its STAB combination. Choice Specs further facilitates Rotom's wallbreaking power by letting it nab 2HKOs on most walls, while its solid Speed allows it to revenge kill a weakened Skuntank or Rotom-S. Volt Switch lets Rotom gain momentum on Water- and Flying-types and get out of bad matchups against threats such as Eldegoss and Appletun. Trick can be used not only to immediately cripple the aforementioned specially defensive walls but also to punish Ground-types that may attempt to block its Volt Switch attempts, such as Stunfisk and Piloswine.

Rotom is susceptible to being revenge killed by faster Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Silvally-Dark if it is locked into Shadow Ball; therefore, it is imperative that you pair Rotom with Fighting- or Fairy-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, Alcremie, and Clefairy. The aforementioned Fighting-types also benefit from Rotom's ability to break past physical walls such as Tangela and Uxie and can deal with Normal-types like Kangaskhan and Miltank so Rotom can use Shadow Ball more freely. Pivots such as Wishiwashi and Silvally formes make for great partners, as they can bring Rotom in safely and form a solid VoltTurn core. Tangela and Appletun can switch into Ground-types like Stunfisk and Rhydon should Rotom lock into an Electric-type move.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot Rotom is a great wallbreaker on offensive teams. With a single boost, Rotom OHKOes physical walls such as Tangela and Poliwrath and has a chance to 2HKO specially defensive walls such as Wishiwashi and Articuno. Substitute lets Rotom block status attempts from Altaria and Miltank and set up on them freely.
