Thwackey can lure in Flying-types and bring in Rotom safely so it can freely set up with Nasty Plot. In return, Rotom can break past physical walls such as Tangela, Poliwrath, and Altaria, which Thwackey struggles with. Late-game cleaners such Alcremie and Quiver Dance Frosmoth benefit greatly from Rotom's ability to weaken special walls such as Galarian Stunfisk and Articuno. Teleport Clefairy and physically defensive Wishiwashi are great defensive pivots that can absorb Dark-type attacks from revenge killers like Silvally-Dark and Choice Scarf Sawk. Rotom also appreciates having Knock Off users like Shiftry and Alolan Persian to weaken special walls such as Throh and Clefairy.

Rotom-Fan.comments:
Other Options

Thunder Wave and Toxic are valid replacements for Will-O-Wisp, but the former is punished by switching into Ground-types, which already don‚Äôt fear Rotom-S's other moves, and the latter allows switch-ins such as Galarian Stunfisk to come in more easily. Discharge can used as Rotom-S's Electric-type STAB move to paralyze offensive switch-ins but leaves it worse off versus bulkier Pokemon. Rotom-S can be a team's Choice Scarf user, but its weakness to Stealth Rock, vulnerability to common priority moves such as Ice Shard, and direct competition with Rotom make it suboptimal for that role.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Ground-types: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Galarian Stunfisk, and Rhydon block Rotom-S's Volt Switch and Thunderbolt and take little from Air Slash. All of them, however, don‚Äôt appreciate taking a Will-O-Wisp on the switch.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers with moves to hit Rotom-S hard such as Cinccino and Silvally formes are able to pressure it out with ease.

Toxic: Taking Toxic from users such as Altaria, Alolan Persian, and Miltank cripples Rotom-S due to its unreliable recovery.

Knock Off: Knock Off users like Sawk, Thwackey, and Gurdurr are difficult for Rotom-S to consistently switch into. Entry hazard setters with access to Knock Off such as Uxie and Clefairy also make it hard for Rotom-S to consistently remove entry hazards throughout a game.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Rotom-S is one of the premier entry hazard removers in the metagame due to its ability to pivot with Volt Switch and excellent defensive typing that lets it wall and threaten common Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Sawk. Will-O-Wisp allows Rotom-S to cripple physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rhydon on the switch, while Pain Split gives greater but unreliable longevity. 252 Speed EVs let Rotom-S outspeed relevant Pokemon such as Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Choice Band Sawk. Investing in Special Attack over HP to pressure common walls like Altaria, Cofagrigus, and Piloswine is also viable.

Rotom-S fits on balance and offense teams as an entry hazard remover and pivot. Common VoltTurn teammates like Silvally-Dark, Wishiwashi, and Uxie can form a pivot core with Rotom-S to safely bring in wallbreakers such as Frosmoth and Shiftry. Toxic cripples Rotom-S, so Toxic-immune partners such as Qwilfish and Clefairy are greatly appreciated; Rotom-S in turn provides them with a switch-in to Ground-type attacks. Knock Off hinders Rotom-S's ability to remove entry hazards, so Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Skuntank help immensely. Rotom-S is unable to deal with hard-hitting wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rapidash, so strong revenge killers such as Cinccino, Alolan Persian, and Choice Scarf Sawk are all great teammates.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Rotom-S's decent Speed along with an excellent offensive typing give it a niche as a stallbreaker and cleaner with Nasty Plot. Substitute allows Rotom-S to avoid crippling status from passive Pokemon such as Clefairy and Altaria, which, in conjunction with its STAB Thunderbolt, lets it beat the only Unaware user in the tier in Pyukumuku. Pain Split, on the other hand, gives Rotom-S more longevity against weak attackers without status such as Cofagrigus, Galarian Stunfisk, and Uxie.

Rotom-S is fits on offensive teams for its stallbreaking and cleaning capabilities. Teammates such as Silvally formes, Kangaskhan, and Basculin appreciate Rotom-S dealing with bulky Pokemon such as Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria. Faster offensive Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Rapidash, and Silvally formes are able to threaten Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Cofagrigus, Piloswine, and Galarian Stunfisk and fast attackers like Alolan Persian, Basculin, and Choice Scarf Sawk are vital for it. Ground-type Pokemon such as Piloswine and Rhydon are able to stomach an unboosted attack from Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Wishiwashi, Tangela, and Miltank are appreciated.

Uxie.comments:
Other Options

Uxie can run a specially defensive spread on its defensive set to better handle special attackers such as Ninetales and Manectric at the expense of switching into Sawk, Rhydon, and Gurdurr. Leftovers is an alternative to Colbur Berry on Uxie's defensive set, providing reliable recovery and improving its longevity. However, this makes Uxie vulnerable to Knock Off. Thunder Wave is a viable alternative to Knock Off that cripples faster attackers such as Thievul, Cinccino, and Silvally formes, letting Uxie's teammates take them on more easily. Defensive Uxie can also run Choice Scarf with Trick and 64 Speed EVs, letting it outspeed up to Cinccino and Alolan Persian and cripple a potential entry hazard remover like Articuno or Coalossal. However, Uxie can get a crippling item like Skuntank's Black Sludge or Rotom's Choice Specs, or even become setup fodder for Silvally formes due to their Trick immunity. Memento is an alternative for the defensive pivot set, blocking Defog and bringing in a teammate more safely than U-turn, but Uxie often can't fit it. Encore can be used to punish Pokemon that otherwise freely set up on Uxie like Galarian Rapidash and Ninetales.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Uxie is threatened by attackers such as Rotom and Gourgeist-S. However, most of them take great damage from Knock Off and STAB moves, meaning Uxie can pressure them on the switch.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Thievul, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank threaten Uxie with their super effective STAB moves, block Future Sight, and can sponge boosted Draining Kiss. However, most take heavy damage from U-turn, and Colbur Berry Uxie can afford to take a hit.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Defensive sweepers such as Alcremie and Spiritomb easily set up on the weak Uxie. This also includes Substitute users such as Frosmoth. Most of them can also beat Uxie in a setup war.

Wallbreakers and Stallbreakers: Wallbreakers such as Thwackey and Basculin can use Uxie's passivity to threaten its whole team with their powerful moves. However, they dislike losing Choice Band or Choice Specs to Knock Off. Faster Taunt users such as Alolan Persian can shut down Uxie's utility and take advantage of it with Toxic.

Steel-types: Setup Uxie sets have a very hard time breaking through Steel-types such as Perrserker and Klinklang due to its low damage output. They can easily break Uxie's Substitute and remove Uxie before it is boosted enough.

Haze Articuno and Pyukumuku: Haze Articuno and Unaware Pyukumuku can wall most setup Uxie. However, Pyukumuku has to be wary of Stored Power's increased Base Power.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Uxie can act as a terrifying late-game cleaner with its Nasty Plot set. Substitute lets it avoid status such as Toxic from Articuno and Altaria, dodge Knock Off from Tangela and Clefairy, and sponge hits from weak attackers like Eldegoss, Clefairy lacking Seismic Toss, and Stunfisk. Psyshock is preferred over Psychic as a STAB move to get around special walls like Articuno and Clefairy more easily. Draining Kiss lets Uxie break through Dark-types like Thievul and Morpeko after a boost and provides coveted recovery.

Uxie is a great late-game cleaner for bulkier teams that can weaken its checks over time. Therefore, entry hazard support, especially Spikes from setters such as Coalossal and Qwilfish, is invaluable. Knock Off support is similarly valuable for removing Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, the latter being the only form of recovery of Steel-types that check Uxie like Klinklang and Perrserker. Toxic users such as Altaria and Rapidash cripple the likes of Haze Articuno, Alcremie, and Musharna to help Uxie break through them. Uxie can also fit well with other defensive sweepers like Spiritomb and Alcremie, weakening each other‚Äôs checks and forcing Trick uses to ensure one of them can sweep.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Uxie is a premier defensive pivot in VoltTurn teams due to its incredible role compression as the only viable Pokemon with both U-turn and Stealth Rock. Additionally, Uxie's incredible bulk lets it reliably check threats like Sawk and Silvally-Poison. Levitate also helps in that regard, avoiding chip damage from Spikes and giving it switch-in opportunities on Rhydon and Piloswine. Yawn allows Uxie to avoid being setup fodder and force out entry hazard removers like Altaria, Articuno, and Coalossal and therefore keep Stealth Rock up. Knock Off lets Uxie remove important items like Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno, Cramorant, and Altaria and Eviolite from Piloswine, Rhydon, and Tangela. Future Sight lets Uxie's partners threaten their checks with the extra, delayed damage. Colbur Berry allows Uxie to counter Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr by weakening their Knock Off; it also lets Uxie take a hit from strong Dark-type wallbreakers such as Thievul, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry and pivot out with a super effective U-turn.

Uxie can form a VoltTurn core with other pivots such as Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Wishiwashi. Such cores are beneficial to wallbreakers that prefer safe switches like Silvally formes, Thievul, and Sawk. Dark-types like Silvally-Dark and Skuntank value Uxie's ability to wall Fighting-types like Sawk and can, in return, threaten Ghost-types like Gourgeist-S and Rotom. Physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes appreciate Future Sight threatening physical walls such as Miltank, Qwilfish, and Tangela. Uxie lacks recovery and gets quickly worn down by Toxic; other walls like Clefairy, Wishiwashi, and Qwilfish can absorb status and take attacks that Uxie can't afford to take. Clefairy also has Aromatherapy to cure Uxie of any status. Pokemon like Poliwrath and Jynx pressure hazard removers like Coalossal, Articuno, and Altaria, helping keep up Uxie's Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Uxie finds a spot in Electric Terrain teams as a Calm Mind sweeper. Stored Power has insane power after Calm Mind and Electric Seed, letting Uxie break through bulkier foes like Articuno and Pyukumuku. Draining Kiss lets Uxie threaten Dark-types like Thievul and Silvally-Dark. Rest is Uxie's best form of recovery, also letting it deal with status from special walls like Articuno lacking Haze and Clefairy. The given spread allows Uxie to outspeed Timid Exeggutor.

Pincurchin is a necessary partner for Electric Surge. Other Electric Seed sweepers like Musharna, Swoobat, Drifblim, and Galarian Rapidash can weaken shared checks, forming a Calm Mind spam core. Electric-types like Raichu and Manectric also appreciate Electric Terrain and can break through special walls, making it easier for Uxie and the other Calm Mind users. In return, Uxie can set up on Ground-types that wall Raichu and Manectric thanks to Levitate.

sets.name: Offense Lead
sets.description:
Uxie's great Speed and amazing bulk make it a great supporter for offensive teams, being able to set Stealth Rock and then cripple the opposing Pokemon with Memento, Encore, or Yawn, giving switching and setup opportunities to teammates. Since this set isn't running any offensive move, Mental Herb is the preferred item to not get completely invalidated by Taunt users like Skuntank, Golbat, and Alolan Persian.

Setup spam offense teams really enjoy Uxie's role compression, creating setup opportunities and providing Stealth Rock. Therefore, offensive setup users like Crustle, Frosmoth, and Silvally formes make for great partners. Pokemon that can advantage of Taunt users that Uxie invites in, such as Alcremie, Double Dance Rhydon, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. Gourgeist-S can prevent Rapid Spin attempts, while Taunt users like Skuntank and Qwilfish deny Defog.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
Thanks to its great bulk and higher Speed than common Taunt users such as Skuntank, Qwilfish, and Sawk, Uxie is capable of reliably setting sun and Stealth Rock several times. U-turn brings sun attackers safely onto the field. Yawn forces out foes that would attempt to set up on Uxie such as Skuntank and Ninetales, which works well with Uxie's fast U-turn. Memento can alternatively be used to provide similar opportunities to Yawn and U-turn in one turn at the cost of sacrificing Uxie.

Sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Leafeon, Ivysaur, and Rapidash love Uxie's ability to reliably set sun. Prankster Liepard is a reliable secondary weather setter to support the team. An offensive sun setter such as Exeggutor creates more opportunities to set it up.

Liepard.comments:
Other Options

Liepard has other useful support options like Taunt and Thunder Wave; however, it lacks room for them.

Checks and Counters

Fighting- and Fairy-types: Sawk, Poliwrath, and Alcremie take little from Liepard's moves and OHKO it back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr easily tanks Dark Pulse and OHKOes Liepard after slight chip damage.

Special Walls: Nasty Plot sets need several boosts to break through special walls such as Articuno and Wishiwashi, which can stall Liepard with Toxic or outright 2HKO it with their attacks.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank are immune to Prankster, resist Liepard's STAB moves, and defeat it with their secondary STAB or coverage moves. However, they have to watch out for U-turn.

Strong Attackers: Because of its poor bulk, Liepard gets OHKOed by strong attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Basculin. Liepard is forced out by them unless it manages to lock them into unfavorable moves with Encore.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
The combination of Prankster and Sunny Day lets Liepard act as an excellent mid-game sun setter. U-turn lets it pivot into a teammate that benefits from sun, such as Shiftry and Ivysaur. Knock Off helps Liepard further support its teammates by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno and Altaria. Encore locks foes such as Silvally-Poison and Uxie into unfavorable moves like Work Up and Stealth Rock, giving Liepard free turns to set up sun and pivot with U-turn. Heat Rock is necessary to provide as many sun turns as possible to Liepard's partners.

Liepard is a must-have on sun teams and is appreciated by sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Ivysaur, and Rapidash. Uxie's sun setter set also fits well on sun teams for its capacity to reliably set Stealth Rock and sun for its team. Furthermore, a third sun setter such as Exeggutor provides more possibilities to set up sun.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Thanks to its high Speed tier and access to Nasty Plot and a pseudo-priority move in Prankster Copycat, Liepard separates itself from other Nasty Plot sweepers such as Skuntank and Alolan Persian. Copycat is mainly used to call Dark Pulse and prevent faster foes like Cinccino, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Basculin from revenge killing a Nasty Plot-boosted Liepard. Encore provides Liepard setup opportunities by locking foes such as Piloswine and Articuno into undesirable moves. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on VoltTurn teams to help Liepard avoid entry hazards and potentially pivot. Black Glasses are an alternative that makes up for Liepard's average Special Attack, making it require less chip damage to clean.

VoltTurn support from pivots such as Uxie, Articuno, and Rotom helps Liepard come on the field in spite of its lackluster bulk. Special wallbreakers such as Ninetales, Rotom, and Basculin can soften opposing special walls in order to let Liepard clean late game. Checks to Fighting-types such as Uxie, Qwilfish, and Rotom-S take on Sawk and Gurdurr, which force Liepard out. Likewise, checks to Fairy-types like Klinklang, Silvally-Poison, and Rapidash are great partners that handle Alcremie and Clefairy. Checks to Dark-types such as Alcremie, Gurdurr, and Sawk are also appreciated, as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can take on Liepard. Kangaskhan is a threat because of Fake Out outprioritizing Copycat, letting it easily revenge kill a weakened Liepard; therefore, checks like Uxie, Tangela, and Cofagrigus are appreciated.

Unfezant.comments:
Other Options

A utility set with Heavy-Duty Boots, Roost, and Defog is feasible, as this set gives Unfezant reliable recovery and allows it to be an offensive entry hazard remover. However, the listed sets more naturally play to Unfezant's strengths, and this set struggles even more against hazard setters like Coalossal, Rhydon, and Qwilfish due to its reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots.

Checks and Counters

Rock- and Steel-types: Rhydon, Coalossal, Perrserker, and Klinklang resist Unfezant's STAB moves, fear none of its coverage, and threaten OHKOs or significant damage with their STAB moves. Rhydon and Coalossal can also set or remove entry hazards, and Coalossal's Flame Body deters Unfezant from pivoting or attacking. However, Perrserker and Klinklang can be worn down by the Choice Band set and fail to reliably switch in later on.

Stealth Rock: Unfezant‚Äôs weakness to Stealth Rock and recoil from Brave Bird quickly wear it down, causing it to faint rather quickly.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom formes and Stunfisk can stomach a hit from both Unfezant sets and threaten to OHKO in return with their super effective STAB moves. Stunfisk also has Static to discourage Unfezant from pivoting with U-turn. However, Rotom must be aware of Night Slash from the Choice Band set.

Faster Offensive Threats: While none of them can safely switch in, Pokemon like Jynx, Rapidash, and Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom can KO Choice Band Unfezant with minimal to no prior chip damage due to its mediocre bulk. However, they must also be aware of Choice Scarf sets, which they can't check.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Unfezant is a powerful wallbreaker, able to devastate teams without sturdy Flying-resistant Pokemon such as Rhydon or Coalossal with Choice Band-boosted STAB Brave Bird. U-turn enables Unfezant to pivot out against Stunfisk, Piloswine, and Klinklang, keeping momentum and chipping them. Quick Attack finishes off weakened faster foes like Cinccino and Basculin. Night Slash lets Unfezant OHKO Rotom. Facade instead becomes a very powerful STAB move if Unfezant gets statused. Super Luck gives it better chances to break through Double Dance Alcremie if the latter has gained a Defense boost prior.

Unfezant fits well in offensive teams due to its great power, good Speed tier, and mediocre bulk. It struggles to break past sturdy Flying-resistant Pokemon like Klinklang and Coalossal and could potentially lose momentum against them. Water- and Electric-types pair particularly well, as Pokemon like Wishiwashi, Basculin, and Raichu can force them out with their STAB or coverage moves and bring Unfezant in safely with their pivot moves. In return, Unfezant can form a VoltTurn core with them and force out Grass-types such as Eldegoss, Tangela, and Gourgeist-S, which pressure them. Spikes users, such as Qwilfish and Coalossal, wear down its checks, many of which lack reliable recovery. Entry hazard control from the likes of Eldegoss, Rotom, and Hattrem can ameliorate its Stealth Rock weakness. Hattrem in particular synergizes well, as it can threaten Rhydon and Stunfisk with Giga Drain. Special wallbreakers like Rotom, Basculin, and Jynx can overwhelm physical walls like Rhydon, Pyukumuku, and Miltank that Unfezant has difficulty breaking through. Other Flying-type wallbreakers, like Silvally-Flying and Rotom-S, can overwhelm their checks with repeated STAB Flying-type moves and coverage options.

Gurdurr.comments:
Other Options

Defog is an option to turn Gurdurr into an entry hazard remover that poses good matchups against common entry hazard setters like Piloswine and Rhydon, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Stone Edge targets foes like Frosmoth, Rotom-S, and Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off removing their Heavy-Duty Boots, Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cramorant can threaten to KO Gurdurr.

Physical Walls: Physical walls such as Altaria and Tangela are able to take hits from Gurdurr and pressure it with their STAB attacks. However, they should be wary of Knock Off. Alcremie is a notable foe that is able to take Gurdurr's STAB options and Knock Off and pressure it with its Fairy-type moves.

Chip Damage and Knock Off: It is easy to cripple and wear down Gurdurr, as it is reliant on Drain Punch recovery and Eviolite to check its foes.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Gurdurr is a notable tank in ZU thanks to its good bulk and access to decent recovery through Drain Punch. This recovery lets Gurdurr more consistently set up, letting it accumulate multiple boosts. Gurdurr can utilize Bulk Up mid- or late-game against passive foes like Stunfisk and Eldegoss. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Tangela, Altaria, and Rotom-S. Mach Punch allows Gurdurr to revenge kill foes such as Shiftry and Cinccino. 252 HP and 60 Defense EVs ensure that Gurdurr will only be 3HKOed by Kangaskhan's Double-Edge, while 252 HP and 60 Special Defense EVs allow it to live Choice Specs Hydro Pump from Basculin after Stealth Rock damage. Guts lets Gurdurr absorb Will-O-Wisp from Rapidash and Toxic from Pyukumuku to empower its attacks.

Gurdurr fits on both bulky offense and balance teams due to its solid bulk and ability to generate pressure with both Bulk Up and Mach Punch. Gurdurr appreciates strong offensive support from its teammates to keep initiative throughout the battle, as it is otherwise prone to being worn down by common VoltTurn cores. Wallbreakers such as Rapidash, Silvally formes, and Thievul can threaten physical walls such as Tangela, Gourgeist-XL, and Qwilfish, enabling Gurdurr to better threaten them late-game. Pokemon such as Rotom and Frosmoth benefit from Gurdurr revenge killing foes such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry with Mach Punch; in return, they can threaten Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Cramorant that trouble it.

Throh.comments:
Other Options

Throh can run a wallbreaker set with Flame Orb and Facade; however, it lacks a spammable powerful STAB move, since it is limited to Superpower and Storm Throw. Additionally, Sawk and Silvally-Fighting are usually preferred for their higher Speed tiers and better wallbreaking capabilities. Throh can also attempt to use a Bulk Up set with either Mold Breaker or Guts, with the former giving it the ability to ignore Pyukumuku's Unaware; however, Gurdurr is better at this role due to having Drain Punch for recovery and Mach Punch for priority. A physically defensive set is more effective at checking the likes of Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan, but Throh struggles to absorb status without a specially defensive spread.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Pokemon like Spiritomb, Rotom, and Gourgeist-XL are immune to Throh's STAB moves and can sponge Knock Off. Spiritomb can set up on Throh, while Rotom and Gourgeist-XL annoy it with status. However, Rotom should be careful switching into Knock Off.

Flying-types: Flying-types like Altaria, Rotom-S, and Cramorant resist Throh's STAB moves and can retaliate back with their super effective STAB moves. However, they despise losing their valuable Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Alcremie, Galarian Rapidash, and Shiinotic resist Throh's moves and can threaten it with their super effective STAB moves. Although Clefairy cannot break through Throh, it can cripple Throh with Knock Off or pivot with Teleport into a check.

Physical Wallbreakers: Even if Throh's physical bulk is far from lacking, its reliance on Rest lets it often get overwhelmed by physical wallbreakers like Cinccino, Silvally formes, and Sawk.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types like Uxie, Swoobat, and Musharna resist Throh's STAB moves, don't take much from Knock Off, and threaten it with their STAB moves or Future Sight. Jynx can also break past Throh, but it cannot safely switch into Throh's attacks.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Throh is a very bulky special wall that works especially well on Spikes-stacking teams. Circle Throw lets it phaze switch-ins, which pairs well with entry hazard support. Knock Off cripples checks like Altaria, Alcremie, and Tangela, hits Ghost-types like Rotom and Gourgeist-S, and removes Heavy-Duty Boots, which is appreciated on entry hazard-stacking teams. Rest is Throh's only form of recovery; thanks to Sleep Talk and Guts, Throh acts as a status absorber and lacks passivity while asleep. The given EV spread ets Throh outspeed uninvested base 50 Speed Pokemon such as Piloswine.

Throh appreciates entry hazard support a lot, especially Spikes from setters such as Qwilfish and Coalossal. Spinblockers like Rotom and Gourgeist formes and fast Taunt users like Alolan Persian, Golbat, and Qwilfish can keep up these entry hazards. Rapid Spin users such as Eldegoss and Alolan Sandslash also make for great partners. Additionally, most of them help handle physical attackers Throh struggles to beat such as Sawk and Silvally-Poison. Despite being a good special wall, Throh appreciates being paired with Pokemon that can handle Volt Switch like Eldegoss, Stunfisk, and Manectric; they prevent it from getting chipped by Electric-types like Rotom, Manectric, and Raichu and losing momentum.

Sawk.comments:
Other Options

Poison Jab lets Sawk 2HKO Alcremie and Clefairy, but this requires giving up one of its other coverage moves, which generally isn't preferred because they target more Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Spiritomb, Gourgeist-Super, and Sableye can switch into any of Sawk's attacks with ease. The former can also set up on Sawk with Calm Mind.

Physical Walls: Tangela, Uxie, and Altaria can switch into Sawk and either cripple it with their status moves or deal significant damage with their STAB moves. Tangela and Altaria must be careful of switching into Knock Off and Stone Edge, respectively, as Choice Band Sawk can 2HKO Tangela if it has lost its Eviolite and can KO Altaria with some prior chip damage. While Qwilfish must be wary of switching into Earthquake, it can easily switch into Close Combat and wear Sawk down with Rocky Helmet.

Faster Threats: Faster attackers such as Rotom, Basculin, and Cinccino can revenge kill Sawk if it has been slightly worn down. However, none of them can afford to risk directly switching into one of Sawk's attacks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
With a solid Speed tier and its incredibly high attacking power, Sawk makes for an excellent revenge killer that fits well on offense and balance teams. Choice Scarf allows Sawk to threaten foes such as Alolan Persian, Kangaskhan, and non-Choice Scarf Cinccino. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Rotom, Gourgeist-S, and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Tangela. Earthquake hits Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Skuntank. Stone Edge lets Sawk deal with Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Golbat. Mold Breaker allows Sawk to hit Levitate users such as Uxie and Rotom with Earthquake. Alternatively, Inner Focus allows Sawk to beat Qwilfish with Earthquake, as Inner Focus nullifies its Intimidate, and not flinch from Kangaskhan's Fake Out. However, don't expect to get free turns from Kangaskhan trying to flinch you, as the opponent should notice the absent Mold Breaker activation message.

While Sawk has super effective coverage for Pokemon that resist or are immune to Close Combat, it still needs physical walls such as Uxie, Tangela, and Altaria to be weakened in order to KO them and successfully clean. Therefore, special attackers such as Skuntank, Rotom, and Basculin that can deal with them make for great partners. Entry hazard setters such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Qwilfish help to wear down Sawk's common switch-ins, as most do not have access to reliable recovery. Pivots such as Uxie, Rotom-S, and Wishiwashi circumvent Sawk's mediocre bulk by safely bringing it onto the field, with the former also having access to Future Sight, which dissuades Poison-types from switching in.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Sawk forgoes Choice Scarf's increase in Speed for more wallbreaking power, letting Close Combat net 2HKOs on neutral physical walls like Pyukumuku and Gurdurr. Knock Off pressures Ghost- and Psychic-types like Rotom and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Tangela; Close Combat threatens a 2HKO on Tangela once its Eviolite has been removed. Earthquake punishes Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison, while Stone Edge nails Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Altaria.

Choice Band Sawk is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster Flying- and Psychic-types such as Rotom-S and Jynx, so switch-ins such as Rhydon and Articuno are appreciated. These Pokemon also have the added benefit of providing entry hazards to help wear down its switch-ins. Special setup sweepers such as Frosmoth and Alcremie benefit greatly from Sawk's ability to break past specially defensive walls such as Coalossal. Sawk also appreciates the removal of Ghost-types, so pairing it with Dark-types like Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian is a good idea. Future Sight Uxie is a great partner, as it punishes the physical walls such as Tangela and Altaria that switch in on Sawk and can also pivot Sawk in safely with U-turn. Sawk can also weaken the aforementioned walls into the KO range of physical cleaners like Rapidash and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

Basculin.comments:
Other Options

Surf is more accurate than Hydro Pump, but its lower power makes it less favorable than Hydro Pump. Mystic Water bluffs a Choice item and lures in foes like Ninetales and Altaria, allowing Basculin to potentially revenge kill them with Aqua Jet or Ice Beam. However, the extra power or Speed from Choice items are more beneficial. A physical Choice Scarf seems reasonable, but Hydro Pump's power makes special Choice Scarf sets better.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Wishiwashi, Cramorant, and Poliwrath easily handle Basculin's STAB moves. However, they must be wary of Toxic. Qwilfish does a great job at tanking Basculin's physical attacks, but it cannot deal with Choice Specs sets.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tangela, Appletun, and Eldegoss can switch into Basculin's Water type attacks, but they must be careful of Ice Beam.

Faster Attackers: Faster foes like Cinccino and Manectric are able to revenge kill Basculin, but they have to watch out for Choice Scarf Basculin or Aqua Jet.

Priority Users: Priority users such as Thwackey and Kangaskhan easily remove Basculin due to its poor bulk.

Special Walls: Articuno and Clefairy handle Choice Specs Basculin well, but all of these Pokemon have to watch out for Choice Band Basculin.

Altaria: Altaria can endure physical attacks, take most special attacks, and can switch out to remove Toxic. However, it has to watch out for Ice Beam from special sets.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
As a result of deadly Adaptability-boosted STAB moves, great Speed tier, and unpredictability between special and physical sets, Basculin is a premier special wallbreaker. However, it's incredibly frail, so it has to be cautious of revenge killers like Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Gourgeist-S. Flip Turn allows Basculin to chip switch-ins and checks like Cramorant and Wishiwashi while keeping momentum. Ice Beam deals with some Water-resistant foes like Tangela and Altaria. Toxic cripples foes like Cramorant and Wishiwashi.

Basculin typically fits on offensive and balance teams looking for an immediate special wallbreaker with a solid Speed tier. Choice Specs Basculin provides great support for physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Sawk that have trouble with physical walls. In return, they can deal with special walls like Wishiwashi and Clefairy, which Basculin struggles to break through. Defensive pivots such as Uxie and Articuno can take hits for Basculin and bring it safely on the field with U-turn, while Basculin helps them with its pivoting. This works very well in tandem with entry hazard support from the likes of Coalossal and Rhydon, as it allows Basculin to OHKO targets like Gurdurr. Partners like Ninetales and Frosmoth cover Grass-types like Tangela, while teammates like Thwackey and Rotom handle Water-types like Wishiwashi and Cramorant.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Basculin takes advantage of its respectable Speed tier and Adaptability to tear through Pokemon that normally absorb its special attacks, like Clefairy and Articuno. Flip Turn chips checks such as Altaria and Cramorant while keeping momentum. Aqua Jet helps Basculin revenge kill weakened, faster foes such as Cinccino and Ninetales. Psychic Fangs can be used to provide coverage against Qwilfish and Poliwrath, which can similarly handle the rest of Basculin's attacks well.

Basculin pairs well with special attackers such as Alcremie, Frosmoth, Ninetales, and Rotom, as it can take down special walls like Articuno and Clefairy that its teammates struggle with and also lure in physical walls and use Flip Turn. Defensive pivots like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Articuno let Basculin safely enter the field and can take hits for it. Offensive pivots such as Rotom and Cinccino similarly allow Basculin to safely enter the field by threatening or KOing foes. Basculin pairs nicely with Pokemon that can threaten Water-types such as Rotom, Thwackey, and Manectric. Frosmoth, Rapidash, and Ninetales take care of Grass-types, with Frosmoth notably also checking one of the biggest threats to Basculin in Altaria.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Basculin is a great choice for teams that want a very hard hitting revenge killer and pivot. Flip Turn chips switch-ins such as Cramorant and Clefairy while providing momentum. Ice Beam is great coverage against Pokemon like Altaria and Tangela, which can normally switch into its Water-type attacks. Toxic cripples checks like Cramorant and Wishiwashi.

Choice Scarf Basculin is usually found on offense and balance teams looking for a revenge killer. VoltTurn cores love having Basculin on their team, as it enables these cores with Flip Turn while bulkier pivots like Alolan Persian and Uxie can help Basculin switch in easily. Teammates such as Articuno and Skuntank serve as answers to bulky Grass-types like Tangela and Appletun. Thwackey and Rotom check Water-types that sponge Basculin's attacks and are additional offensive pivots that keep momentum. Lastly, entry hazard removers like Altaria and Rotom-S clear entry hazards that wear down Basculin as it pivots.

Cinccino.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Cinccino from being worn down by entry hazards. Protective Pads can prevent Cinccino from being worn down from residual damage such as Rocky Helmet and Iron Barbs. However, forgoing Choice Band for one of the aforementioned items results in a noticeable loss of power.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr are problematic for Cinccino. Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds and can OHKO it, while Gurdurr can revenge kill Cinccino with Mach Punch.

Ghost-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off, Ghost-types such as Cofagrigus and Rotom check Cinccino by switching into Tail Slap. Both Gourgeist-Small and Rotom can cripple Cinccino with Will-O-Wisp.

Residual Damage: Residual damage from Iron Barbs and Rocky Helmet can severely weaken Cinccino, as each Tail Slap hit connecting results in it being damaged five times. Entry hazards prevent Cinccino from repeatedly switching into battle and can put it in range of a potential revenge killer.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Klinklang and Perrserker are able to handle Tail Slap. However, they should be wary of being weakened by Knock Off and U-turn.

Revenge Killers: Although Cinccino is relatively fast, its mediocre bulk means that Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf users like Basculin and Poliwrath can revenge kill it easily. Similarly, strong priority users like Kangaskhan and Shiftry can also threaten Cinccino.

sets.name: Physical Wallbreaker
sets.description:
The combination of Skill Link + Tail Slap makes Cinccino a notable offensive threat that is able to revenge kill a majority of the ZU metagame. Bullet Seed provides coverage against Rock-types such as Kabutops and Rhydon that resist Tail Slap. Knock Off weakens Ghost-types such as Gourgeist-Small, Rotom, and Sableye, and cripples Eviolite-reliant Pokemon such as Rhydon and Tangela. U-turn is useful for establishing and retaining momentum against the aforementioned Rock-, Steel-, and Ghost-types, while Rock Blast can be used to OHKO Coalossal and Rapidash without activating Flame Body.

Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr complement Cinccino by pressuring problematic Steel- and Rock-types such as Klinklang and Rhydon, easing Cinccino's ability to break through them. Ghost-type checks such as Rotom and Silvally-Dark are also appreciated, handling foes such as opposing Rotom and Gourgeist-Small; in return, Cinccino can form a VoltTurn core with them and safely pivot them into battle. Special wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Basculin and Thievul also appreciate U-turn support, and they can threaten physical walls that switch into Cinccino. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Cramorant and the aforementioned Rotom can alleviate Cinccino's susceptibility to entry hazards from its frequent pivoting.

Beheeyem.comments:
Other Options

A bulky Nasty Plot set with Recover allows Beheeyem to wallbreak outside of Trick Room and better wield Analytic, though Beheeyem becomes even easier to revenge kill because it lacks a way to circumvent its low Speed.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types like Silvally-Dark, Thievul, Choice Band Spiritomb, and Shiftry can switch into Psychic and OHKO Beheeyem with minimal to no prior chip damage, especially if Beheeyem has used its Power Herb. The latter two in particular can OHKO Beheeyem with Sucker Punch, forcing it out most of the time even under Trick Room.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker have enough bulk to stomach at least one hit from Beheeyem and deal massive damage in return. However, they cannot switch in safely.

Special Walls: Special walls like Clefairy and Wishiwashi can take a hit from Beheeyem and stall out Trick Room turns with their terrific bulk. Wishiwashi is able to underspeed Beheeyem even under Trick Room with minimum Speed and heavily chip it with U-turn, while Clefairy can recover damage off with Soft-Boiled and fish for Special Attack drops with Moonblast.

Kangaskhan: Although it cannot switch in, Kangaskhan can repeatedly use Fake Out and waste Trick Room turns, additionally whittling Beheeyem down. After Beheeyem has been weakened enough, Kangaskhan can use Sucker Punch and defeat it.

Faster Wallbreakers: Without Trick Room, Beheeyem's merely passable bulk and poor defensive typing leave it very vulnerable to strong Pokemon that can outspeed it, such as Rotom, Basculin, Jynx, and Perrserker.

sets.name: Trick Room
sets.description:
Thanks to Beheeyem's sky-high Special Attack stat, terrible Speed stat, and access to Trick Room, it is a staple on said archetype. Meteor Beam OHKOes Pokemon that can switch into Psychic like Alolan Persian, Skuntank, and Thievul, OHKOes specially defensive Pokemon like Articuno and Coalossal, and boosts its Special Attack stat without wasting a Trick Room turn on setup when used with Power Herb. Thunderbolt OHKOes Cramorant and 2HKOes Wishiwashi while 2HKOing Articuno at +1. It is also Beheeyem's strongest spammable option against Dark- and Steel-types. Analytic takes advantage of how well Beheeyem forces switches, and it exploits Beeheeyem's very low Speed in the rare instances it attacks outside of Trick Room.

Due to Beheeyem's awful Speed, poor defensive typing, and merely decent bulk, it should mainly be used on dedicated Trick Room teams, as otherwise other Psychic-types and special wallbreakers outclass it. Pivots like Uxie and Perrserker can also lure in physical walls like Qwilfish and Tangela and use U-turn to make Beheeyem's wallbreaking easier. Other Trick Room setters, like Gourgeist-XL, Uxie, and Trevenant, can provide more chances for Beheeyem to attack without needing to set up Trick Room first, and teammates that lack Trick Room especially appreciate these chances. These teammates include Bouffalant, Flame Orb Throh, and Rhydon, which benefit from Beheeyem's wallbreaking and Trick Room, enabling them to more easily break holes against the opposition or clean late-game.

Cryogonal.comments:
Other Options

Rapid Spin can be used over Defog on entry hazard stacking teams to avoid removing Cryogonal's own entry hazards. Haze is also useful against special setup sweepers such as Frosmoth and Rotom-F. A dual screens set with Reflect, Light Screen, and Explosion has a niche on hyper offense teams.

Checks and Counters

Physical Attackers: Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Rhydon, and Silvally formes threaten Cryogonal due to its low physical bulk.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Sawk can threaten to OHKO Cryogonal. Specifically, Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds Cryogonal and OHKOes it, while Gurdurr easily tanks Freeze-Dry and threatens Cryogonal with Drain Punch.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Freeze-Dry and force Cryogonal out.

Steel-types: Klinklang and Perrserker tank Freeze-Dry and can retaliate with their STAB attacks. However, they do not appreciate taking a Knock Off.

Item Removal: Knock Off users such as Uxie, Clefairy, Alolan Persian, and Audino and Trick users like Rotom can threaten to cripple Cryogonal by removing its Heavy-Duty Boots, which makes it vulnerable to Stealth Rock and lowers its ability to switch in.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Cryogonal is a fast, niche Defogger in the metagame that has great special bulk and can offensively pressure Qwilfish. Cryogonal also performs well as a specially defensive wall, checking prevalent special attackers such as Articuno, Rotom formes, and Frosmoth. It has access to reliable recovery in Recover and great utility with the combination of Toxic and Knock Off.

Nonetheless, Cryogonal's low Defense stat and poor defensive typing make it vulnerable to a majority of physical attackers. Altaria can help Cryogonal check both Fire- and Fighting-type moves. Tangela can also check physical attackers such as Sawk, Cinccino, and Gurdurr, which force out Cryogonal. In return, Cryogonal counters special attackers such as Choice Specs Basculin and Frosmoth. On balance builds, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash is a great partner for Cryogonal, handling Steel-types such as Perrserker and Klinklang; in return, Cryogonal is able to pressure its checks such as Altaria and bulky Water-types like Wishiwashi. Water-types like Qwilfish, Poliwrath, and Wishiwashi help check Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which annoy Cryogonal. Bulky Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Throh also pair well with Cryogonal, threatening Steel-types.

Stunfisk.comments:
Other Options

Rest provides Stunfisk with recovery and lets it remove status, but it makes Stunfisk even more passive. Stone Edge or Rock Slide is an option to directly threaten Articuno and Frosmoth. Thunder Wave provides a more reliable method of slowing foes like Sawk and Silvally formes, while Protect synergizes with Toxic and Leftovers, wearing down foes and providing Stunfisk with more recovery. However, Stunfisk often has difficulty fitting either move.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Eldegoss threaten Stunfisk with their attacks or status and force it out. However, they do not appreciate Toxic.

Water-types: Although they cannot directly switch into Discharge or Toxic, Water-types like Basculin, Poliwrath, and Wishiwashi can effectively handle Stunfisk.

Ice-types: Despite its great special bulk, Stunfisk is vulnerable to powerful Ice-types like Frosmoth, Abomasnow, and Jynx.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine target Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery and heavily damage or KO it with their strong attacks.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers like Cinccino, Kangaskhan, and Sawk heavily pressure Stunfisk with their attacks, although they dislike Static.

Residual Damage: Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery leaves it vulnerable to Spikes and Toxic from foes such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Clefairy.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Stunfisk is a notable specially defensive wall and Stealth Rock setter in ZU that has good matchups against common threats like Rotom, Skuntank, and Manectric. Toxic wears down switch-ins like Tangela, Rhydon, and Piloswine and Defoggers like Articuno and Rotom formes. Earth Power prevents Stunfisk from being passive against prominent special attackers like Manectric, Skuntank, and Ninetales. Discharge allows Stunfisk to spread paralysis and deal with most Defoggers, while Foul Play lets it handle Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom and physical setup sweepers like Thwackey, which may try to take advantage of Stunfisk to safely set up. Static punishes physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Alolan Persian, and it can also give Stunfisk a chance to cripple checks like physical Basculin and Thwackey in an emergency situation.

Stunfisk fits primarily on balance and bulky offense teams and provides valuable role compression. Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S handle Water- and Ground-types like Wishiwashi and Rhydon; in return, Stunfisk can take on Poison-types like Silvally-Poison and Skuntank for them. Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales pressure the aforementioned Grass-types, as well as Ice-types like Articuno and Frosmoth, for Stunfisk. As Stunfisk has a poor matchup against other Stealth Rock setters like Rhydon and Piloswine, it is adviseable to pair it with Water-types like Poliwrath, Basculin, and Cramorant; Cramorant is a notable partner that can provide Defog and check powerful foes like Sawk while benefitting greatly from Stunfisk dealing with Electric-types. Toxic absorbers like Altaria and Qwilfish prevent Stunfisk from getting worn down; a Toxic Spikes absorber like Silvally-Poison or Qwilfish is likewise helpful. Cleric support from partners like Clefairy and Alcremie helps Stunfisk remain healthy, especially on bulkier teams.

Stunfisk-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Snap Trap traps and chips down targets while synergizing with Yawn to inflict foes with sleep. However, having one of these moves reduces Galarian Stunfisk's coverage and utility in other areas and leaves it unable to deal with Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom formes; they should only been used in specific situations. Thunder Wave cripples and forces out faster foes like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes; however, it leaves Stunfisk Galarian unable to punish Ground-types. Protect allows Galarian Stunfisk to gain more recovery from Leftovers and lets it scout Choice item users such as Sawk and Rotom. Rest is also used as a recovery option, but it is considerably niche and only fits on select teams. Rest is best used when paired with Heal Bell support from Articuno, Clefairy, or Altaria on stall teams.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types such as Basculin, Cramorant, and Wishiwashi handle Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Gound force out Galarian Stunfisk out, with the former two using that opportunity to set up Stealth Rock and the latter setting up with Swords Dance.

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr threaten Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves, while Cofagrigus can set up with Iron Defense and KO it with Body Press.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Galarian Stunfisk, although they cannot safely switch in due to Galarian Stunfisk's Rock / Ground coverage.

Strong Wallbreakers: While Galarian Stunfisk does have great bulk, it can easily get overwhelmed by strong setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Shiftry, Nasty Plot Rotom, and Iron Defense Cofagrigus.

Item Removal: Pokemon such as Knock Off Uxie and Trick Rotom can remove Galarian Stunfisk's main form of recovery in Leftovers, limiting its effectiveness as a special wall.

Spikes: Spikes chips down Galarian Stunfisk over time, limiting its switch-ins and effectiveness as a special wall.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Galarian Stunfisk is a niche Stealth Rock setter in the metagame thanks to its great defensive stats and great defensive typing that lets it wall threats such as Rotom formes and Frosmoth. Rock Slide hits Pokemon such as Cramorant, Articuno, Frosmoth, and the aforementioned Rotom formes; Rock Slide is more consistent than Stone Edge and preferred due to its higher accuracy and PP. Curse turns Galarian Stunfisk into a threatening late-game cleaner while also making up for its passivity. Yawn forces switches from Pokemon that wall Galarian Stunfisk, such as Uxie and Tangela. Foul Play deals significant damage to Swords Dance users such as Silvally formes.

Galarian Stunfisk is a decent pick on balance and stall teams thanks to it compressing the role of an Electric immunity, Stealth Rock setter, and special wall. Bulky Water-types such as Cramorant and Wishiwashi are great partners to Galarian Stunfisk, as they can take on Water-types such as Basculin and Poliwrath, which threaten Galarian Stunfisk, while also benefitting from Galarian Stunfisk's Electric immunity. Grass-types are also great partners to cover Galarian Stunfisk's weaknesses, with Appletun covering its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fire, while Gourgeist-S and Trevenant cover its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fighting. Uxie can also work as a partner, as it is resistant to Fighting and immune to Ground. Spikes stacking teams also appreciate Galarian Stunfisk's ability to force switches with Yawn, with a Spikes setter such as Qwilfish also covering Galarian Stunfisk's weakness to Fighting.

Bouffalant.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band set provides Bouffalant with immediate wallbreaking power and also has the element of surprise. Reckless is used to further increase the power of Head Charge. However, this loses the niche of Grass immunity and faces heavy competition from weaker yet more versatile Normal-types in Kangaskhan, Silvally, and Cinccino.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-type Pokemon such as Sawk, Silvally-Fighting, and Poliwrath all threaten to OHKO Bouffalant with their powerful STAB attacks.

Physical Walls: Miltank and Qwilfish can wear down Bouffalant with Rocky Helmet damage, which adds to Head Charge recoil. Alolan Persian can survive a few hits and prevent setup thanks to Foul Play.

Strong Faster Pokemon: Strong, faster Pokemon such as Perrserker, Silvally-Dark, and Basculin can hit Boufflant hard, preventing it from setting up.

Ghost-types: Sableye and Gourgeist-XL can sponge Bouffalant's attacks and prevent setup with Foul Play and Will-O-Wisp. Rotom can also threaten Bouffalant with Will-O-Wisp but doesn't take Throat Chop very well.

sets.name: Sap Sipper Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Bouffalant finds its niche in ZU as a bulky wallbreaker with a great ability in Sap Sipper. Sap Sipper allows Bouffalant to prey on ZU's Grass-types, such as the common blanket physical walls Tangela and Eldegoss, using them as setup fodder with Substitute and Swords Dance. In addition, Bouffalant checks offensive Grass-type threats in Thwackey and Gourgeist-S. Head Charge is Bouffalant's standard STAB move thanks to its high power. Facade is sometimes used over Substitute and takes advantage of status. This then frees up Close Combat as a coverage option, which hits Pokemon that resist Bouffalant's STAB move such as Rhydon, Klingklang, and Coalossal. Throat Chop is used to hit Ghost-types like Rotom, Gourgeist formes, and Trevenant. The EV spread allows Bouffalant to outspeed uninvested Tangela, Eldegoss, and Alcremie whilst increasing bulk.

Bouffalant fits well on balance and bulky offense teams, helping break down defensive teams that rely on passive Pokemon to deal damage. Thwackey is a great partner for Bouffalant, as it can lure in Tangela and Eldegoss before pivoting out with U-turn, bring in Bouffalant safely, and provide additional passive recovery on top of Leftovers. Kabutops and Morpeko are other pivots that can force Grass-types in. Strong special attackers such as Basculin, Thievul, and Appletun can help break through other physically bulky Pokemon such as Rhydon, Qwilfish, and Miltank. Uxie and Qwillfish can compress the roles of entry hazard setter and switch-in to Fighting-type attacks that threaten Bouffalant. Dark-type Pokemon such as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can help pressure Ghost-types like Rotom and Sableye, which are immune to Bouffalant's STAB moves. Lastly, late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk, Thwackey, and Cinccino can benefit from Bouffalant's wallbreaking abilities.

Malamar.comments:
Other Options

An EV spread of 252 HP / 184 SpD / 72 Spe allows Malamar to outspeed Perrserker, Piloswine, and Jolly Rhydon, at the cost of no longer avoiding a 3HKO from Jynx and Ninetales. A physically defensive spread with an Impish nature enables Malamar to better take on Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Rapidash, but it makes Malamar worse against special attackers like Rotom and Jynx. Psycho Cut grants Malamar a more reliable way to break down Fighting-types like Throh and Gurdurr, as well as opposing Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison. It also serves as Malamar's best way to damage Alcremie after boosts, but Knock Off offers too much utility to forego except on an offensive set with three attacks + Substitute or Taunt. A Choice Scarf set with Switcheroo over Sleep Talk can cripple checks like Alcremie and Pyukumuku, although this set makes Malamar more passive due to lacking Leftovers and renders it more susceptible to strong attackers like Thwackey and Rapidash.

Checks and Counters

U-turn: Pokemon such as Wishiwashi and Silvally-Poison can switch into Malamar and force it out with U-turn. More offensive Pokemon like Flapple, Perrserker, Thwackey, and Cinccino can also scare it out, although they are unable to switch in safely and dislike losing their items to Knock Off.

Strong Wallbreakers: While most can't directly switch into it, Malamar's initial bulk and mediocre Speed tier allow dangerous wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Basculin, Choice Band Morpeko, and Swords Dance Silvally-Poison to heavily damage it.

Fairy-types: Alcremie can either 3HKO Malamar or use it as setup fodder; however, mono-attacking Stored Power variants of Alcremie are unable to beat Malamar. Clefairy can beat it comfortably in a one-on-one, although a +1 Malamar can beat a Clefairy that switches in. Both Fairy-types also dislike losing their items.

Pyukumuku: Unaware ignores Malamar's stat boosts and causes it to deal little damage to Pyukumuku. Pyukumuku can then trap Malamar with Block and proceed to stall it out.

Bulky Ghost-types: Sableye and Gourgeist-XL can stop Malamar from using Superpower and allow themselves to be hit with a weak Knock Off, preventing it from gaining boosts. Spiritomb dislikes losing its item, but it can use its neutrality to Knock Off to turn Malamar into setup fodder or attack it.

sets.name: Contrary Stallbreaker
sets.description:
Malamar serves as a disruptive stallbreaker thanks to its Contrary-boosted Superpower, STAB Knock Off, and decent bulk. Its ability Contrary allows Malamar to take advantage of teams relying on Defog to clear hazards, Intimidate and Parting Shot to deal with physical attackers, and stat drops from moves like Shadow Ball and Grav Apple. Superpower allows Malamar to simultaneously boost and break past walls like Tangela, Stunfisk, and Articuno. Knock Off OHKOes non-Colbur Berry Rotom and weakens switch-ins like Alcremie, Clefairy, and Thwackey. The combination of Rest and Sleep Talk enables Malamar to either continue boosting with Superpower or removing items via Knock Off while also enabling it to outstall foes like Alolan Persian, Cramorant, and Altaria. A specially defensive spread alongside Leftovers lets Malamar avoid the 3HKO from Pokemon such as Ninetales, Cramorant, and Choice Scarf Jynx, although it must be wary of switching into the latter's Trick.

Malamar appreciates entry hazard support from teammates like Qwilfish and Rhydon to wear down threats like Silvally-Poison and Sawk. In return, it can switch into Defoggers like Articuno and Cramorant and deter them while also reliably breaking down common defensive walls like Tangela and Stunfisk. Malamar's teammates appreciate it breaking down, or at least weakening, special attackers such as Ninetales and Skuntank. This enables offensive teammates like Silvally-Poison and Thwackey to clean late-game. As a result of its massive weakness to U-turn, Pokemon such as Rocky Helmet Miltank and Qwilfish, and Flame Body Rapidash are helpful to deter pivots like Cinccino and Thwackey.

Wishiwashi.comments:
Other Options

Wishiwashi can opt for a physically defensive spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with a Bold or Impish nature to better handle physical attackers such as Rhydon and Rapidash at the cost of losing the ability to reliably check special attackers such as Ninetales.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Offensive Grass-types such as Flapple and Gourgeist-S are able to OHKO Wishiwashi, while Thwackey and Shiftry can KO Wishiwashi with a bit of prior chip. However, these Pokemon, particularly Shiftry, must be careful of switching into U-turn. Defensive Grass-types such as Appletun and Tangela can deal with Wishiwashi and do not take much from its attacks, but they must be wary of Toxic.

Electric-types: The Rotom formes and Manectric threaten Wishiwashi out with their STAB attacks, with the former also being able to cripple it with Trick.

Residual Damage: Entry hazards limit the number of times Wishiwashi can safely switch in and wear it down to Solo Form much faster. Altaria, Articuno, and Clefairy can also cripple non-RestTalk Wishiwashi variants with Toxic.

Knock Off: Wishiwashi is reliant on Leftovers as its means of recovery, so Knock Off users such as Gurdurr, Alolan Persian, and Clefairy can reduce Wishiwashi's longevity.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
With access to a slow U-turn and naturally high defenses, Wishiwashi makes for an excellent slow pivot and mixed wall, checking the likes of Rapidash and Basculin. Scald can burn physical attackers such as Gourgeist-S and Flapple that attempt to switch in, while Liquidation is a guaranteed OHKO on Fire-types such as Ninetales. Wishiwashi can opt for Rest for some much needed instant recovery. Sleep Talk should be used in conjunction with Rest in order to avoid being overly passive when asleep. Rest Wishiwashi is also a great status absorber, making it a more reliable pivot against stall teams. Alternatively, Toxic cripples bulkier foes like Appletun and Tangela, as well as dissuading setup sweepers like Frosmoth and Swoobat from switching in. Protect synergizes well with Toxic and lets Wishiwashi scout attacks from Choiced-locked Pokemon such as Rotom, Cinccino, and Sawk. Additionally, Protect lets Wishiwashi acquire more Leftovers recovery, which is essential for staying above Schooling's deactivation threshold.

The best use of Wishiwashi's slow U-turn is to pair it with offensive threats such as Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Shiftry that typically struggle to switch into attacks. Pivots such as the Rotom formes and Uxie make for great Wishiwashi partners, as they can form a VoltTurn core to keep momentum while wearing down foes. Wishiwashi's lack of reliable recovery means it is very vulnerable to being worn down by entry hazards; Defog users such as Rotom-S and Articuno help to alleviate this issue. Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine appreciate Wishiwashi's slow U-turn, and in return, they can deal with Electric-types such as Rotom, Rotom-S, and Morepeko. Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Ninetales and Skuntank are good Pokemon to pair with Wishiwashi, as they can switch into Pokemon like Shiftry, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S that threaten Wishiwashi out.

Pyukumuku.comments:
Other Options

Pyukumuku can sometimes forgo Block to run Rest with both Spite and Toxic. Soak lets Pyukumuku inflict Toxic poison on Steel- and Poison-types Klinklang and Silvally-Poison and helps it better take on Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Klinklang, and other Silvally formes by making them lose their STAB bonus.

Checks and Counters

Taunt: Pyukumuku is forced to use Struggle if it gets afflicted by Taunt. Taunt users like Skuntank, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish beat Pyukumuku, but some of them should be wary of being inflicted by Toxic poison on the switch.

Substitute: Substitute users such as Rotom, Klinklang, and Articuno are major threats to Pyukumuku due to them being immune to Block and Toxic; however, PP stalling with Spite and Rest can help against them.

Electric- and Grass-types: Since Pyukumuku is weak to Grass- and Electric-type moves, Pokemon such as Rotom formes, Shiftry, and Flapple are big threats to it.

Strong Wallbreakers: Strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Sawk and Cinccino 2HKO Pyukumuku.

Stored Power Users: After several Calm Minds, Alcremie, Musharna, Uxie, and Swoobat can overcome Pyukumuku's Unaware with Stored Power. They also have Substitute or Rest to combat Toxic.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Pyukumuku is the sole viable user of Unaware in ZU, making it a cornerstone on stall teams. Unaware allows Pyukumuku to take on setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Rhydon, non-Stored Power Alcremie, and Silvally formes. Block prevents the foe from switching and allows Pyukumuku to remove them with Toxic or PP stall with Spite. Rest removes status and helps to PP stall foes that cannot 3HKO Pyukumuku, such as Choice Scarf Sawk. Leftovers is normally preferred when entry hazard removal is prevalent on the team, while Heavy-Duty Boots may be used to help against entry hazard stacking matchups.

Pyukumuku's passive nature limits it to fitting exclusively on stall teams. Specially defensive clerics such as Clefairy and Articuno form a good core with Pyukumuku. Physically defensive Pokemon such as Altaria, Tangela, and Golbat, which can take on offensive Grass-types, make for good partners with Pyukumuku. Pokemon that can beat Electric-types such as Rotom-S and block Volt Switch such as Stunfisk are also great partners. If not running Heavy-Duty Boots, or if the item gets removed, Pyukumuku can take big damage from entry hazards and have a harder time checking Silvally-Dark and Rapidash. To avoid this, entry hazard removers such as Altaria, Articuno, and Eldegoss are essential on stall teams.

Type: Null.comments:
Other Options

A set with Iron Defense / Swords Dance / Crush Claw / Rest and an EV spread of 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD is sometimes used to turn Type: Null into an unbreakable and powerful sweeper. However, this set is not consistent due to it only having Normal-type coverage and is walled by the common Ghost-types in the tier; in addition, it is passive thanks to the lack of Sleep Talk. This set also lacks the utility of the pivot set, and Type: Null also needs multiple boosts to become threatening due to its low Attack stat.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon: Type: Null is weak to Fighting, so it should be careful of Pokemon like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Strong physical wallbreakers such as Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes can muscle their way through Type: Null.

Knock Off: Any Pokemon with Knock Off is a threat, as losing Eviolite significantly decreases Type: Null's bulk.

Taunt: Taunt users such as Skuntank and Qwilfish stop Type: Null from recovering and spreading status, forcing it to pivot.

Setup Sweepers that Bypass Toxic: Setup sweepers with Substitute such as Rotom formes can freely set up in front of Type: Null. Poison- and Steel-types such as Skuntank and Klinklang, as well as Pokemon that can cure status like Spiritomb and Aromatherapy Alcremie, can also set up for free.

Entry Hazards: Although Type: Null is not weak to Stealth Rock, its lack of passive recovery and constant pivoting cause it to get easily chipped down, limiting the amount of times it can switch in and lowering its usefulness as a wall.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Type: Null acts as a niche defensive pivot in the metagame thanks to its sizable bulk with Eviolite and access to U-turn. This bulk allows it to check top-tier special wallbreakers such as Basculin, Ninetales, and Thievul. Type: Null's slow U-turn allows it to pivot and safely bring in a teammate. Toxic cripples foes and prevents Pokemon such as Rhydon, Rapidash, and Silvally formes from freely setting up in front of it. RestTalk is Type: Null's only form of recovery and lets it consistently pivot. A Sassy nature and 0 Speed IVs minimize Type: Null's Speed, allowing for the slowest U-turns.

Type: Null is a great pick for teams looking for a pivot, special wall, and status absorber condensed into one Pokemon. It pairs well with other pivots, forming a VoltTurn core. Uxie is an excellent pivot to pair with Type: Null, as it benefits from Type: Null's immunity to Ghost and ability to sponge strong special hits; in return, Uxie is able to switch into strong Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr that trouble Type: Null. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Basculin, and Perrserker appreciate Type: Null's slow U-turn safely bringing them in. Although Type: Null can sponge special wallbreakers, it cannot do much damage back and is heavily dependent on pivoting into revenge killers to adequately check special sweepers. Thus, priority users like Kangaskhan and Gurdurr are necessary when dealing with foes such as Shiftry and Frosmoth. Finally, Knock Off absorbers such as Qwilfish and Silvally formes work as partners, as they prevent Type: Null from losing its Eviolite.

Silvally-Dark.comments:
Other Options

X-Scissor is an option over U-turn for a stronger move to threaten opposing Dark-types. Toxic can be used to cripple physical walls such as Tangela and Pyukumuku, but it makes Silvally-Dark less effective at wallbreaking. Defog provides role compression, and it is a niche option on certain teams.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Although they do not appreciate U-turn, Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank can take Multi-Attack from Silvally-Dark and threaten it back with status or a powerful hit.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr are able to take Multi-Attack and pressure back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr can also revenge kill Silvally-Dark with Mach Punch, even after it has set up; Choice Scarf Sawk can similarly revenge kill it due to outspeeding it. However, all Fighting-types should be wary of +2 Psychic Fangs.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Shiinotic can threaten Silvally-Dark with their STAB options, but they have to watch out for Iron Head variants.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers such as Basculin, Rapidash, and Cinccino can outspeed and threaten Silvally-Dark. Pokemon with priority moves such as Kangaskhan and Thwackey can similarly KO it once it has been weakened.

sets.name: Swords Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Silvally-Dark finds a niche in ZU as a powerful setup sweeper, capable of setting up with Swords Dance and utilizing its Multi-Attack to threaten prominent Pokemon such as Uxie, Spiritomb, and Rotom. However, it faces competition from other Silvally formes. U-turn allows Silvally-Dark to function as an early-game pivot and lets it weaken Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, while Flame Charge allows it to outspeed revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Basculin. Psychic Fangs can be used to threaten Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Sawk, while Iron Head weakens Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy.

Silvally-Dark fits best on offensive teams as an early-game pivot that can wallbreak with its powerful Multi-Attack. If running Flame Charge, Silvally-Dark should be preserved for late-game, when it can set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge and sweep. Silvally-Dark has trouble with Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, so checks to them such as Alcremie and Piloswine, respectively, are appreciated. Checks to Fighting-types such as Rotom-S, Qwilfish, and the aforementioned Alcremie are also appreciated, with Rotom-S forming a VoltTurn core with Silvally-Dark and Qwilfish providing Spikes support, weakening foes such as Qwilfish into the range of +2 Multi-Attack. As Silvally-Dark lacks recovery, entry hazard removal from the likes of Rotom-S and Cramorant is necessary to keep Silvally-Dark healthy to keep pivoting with U-turn. Memento support from Uxie can help Silvally-Dark more easily set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge.

Silvally-Fighting.comments:
Other Options

A fully physical Swords Dance set alongside Flame Charge and either Iron Head or Psychic Fangs makes Silvally-Fighting a late-game sweeper. At +2, a healthy Silvally-Fighting can lure in and defeat Alcremie with Iron Head, something other Fighting-types like Sawk cannot do, though this set can't beat defensive Pokemon like Qwilfish, Tangela, and Altaria. This set also faces tough competition from other Silvally formes due to their better offensive or defensive typings.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Alcremie and Clefairy do not take much damage from any of Silvally-Fighting's attacks and can freely set up on it, forcing it to switch.

Bulky Pokemon: Articuno, Eldegoss, Stunfisk, and Uxie don't take much damage from even Silvally-Fighting's super effective coverage attacks. Articuno and Eldegoss can heal damage off with Roost and Regenerator, respectively, though Stunfisk and Uxie lack reliable recovery.

Ghost-types: Spiritomb can switch into any of Silvally-Fighting's attacks with impunity and use it as setup fodder. More offensive Ghost-types, like Rotom and Gourgeist-S, are immune to its STAB move and can revenge kill it with prior damage, though they can't repeatedly switch into Silvally-Fighting's coverage.

Faster Pokemon: With some chip damage, faster Pokemon like Cinccino, Ninetales, and Basculin can revenge kill Silvally-Fighting, though they do not want to directly switch into any of its attacks.

sets.name: BoltBeam Pivot
sets.description:
Silvally-Fighting is an excellent mixed wallbreaker and pivot thanks to its typing and movepool beating common Silvally checks, Defoggers, and entry hazard setters like Rhydon, Altaria, and Qwilfish in one teamslot. U-turn maintains momentum and chips bulkier checks like Alcremie, Eldegoss, and Articuno. Thunderbolt 2HKOes Qwilfish and 3HKOes Poliwrath and Wishiwashi, while Ice Beam targets Tangela, Altaria, and Gourgeist-S. These coverage moves allow Silvally-Fighting to beat common Fighting-type checks that would otherwise switch in safely.

Silvally-Fighting fits well on VoltTurn teams thanks to its good Speed tier, bulk, and coverage against defensive staples like Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian. Fast and slow pivots like Rotom formes, Cinccino, Wishiwashi, and Uxie chip down checks like Articuno, Stunfisk, and Rotom. Silvally-Fighting heavily struggles to break through Fairy-types and generally bulky Pokemon like Eldegoss or Stunfisk without support, so partners that can take these Pokemon on, like Alolan Dugtrio, Perrserker, and Piloswine, can help it pivot more easily. In return, Silvally-Fighting can take on bulky staples weak to its coverage, like Tangela and Poliwrath, which the aforementioned Steel-types struggle against. Checks to Rotom and Gourgeist-S, such as Stunfisk, Eldegoss, and Sap Sipper Miltank, are appreciated. Stunfisk and Miltank can use Toxic to wear down checks to Silvally-Fighting, like Articuno and opposing Stunfisk. Eldegoss and Miltank can provide cleric support to alleviate Silvally-Fighting's vulnerability to residual damage.

Silvally-Poison.comments:
Other Options

Ice Beam is an option over Surf for mixed sets, allowing Silvally-Poison to OHKO Altaria while keeping neutral coverage on the whole tier bar Piloswine when paired with Thunderbolt. However, this leaves Silvally-Poison far less consistent versus Ground- and Rock-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Coalossal. Parting Shot can be used over U-turn on Defog sets, but U-turn's damage is often preferred and Klinklang's Clear Body would prevent Silvally-Poison from freely pivoting. Surf and Thunderbolt are options over U-turn and Flame Charge on Swords Dance Silvally-Poison, giving it better coverage. Grass Pledge is a coverage move hitting Ground-types like Rhydon and Stunfisk while still hitting Water-types like Kabutops and Qwilfish, but it is signficantly weaker than Surf + Thunderbolt.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Even if carrying Surf, Silvally-Poison needs to heavily weaken Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk before sweeping.

Rotom: Rotom resists Silvally-Poison's STAB Multi-Attack and can threaten it back with its STAB moves or a burn with Will-O-Wisp. However, sets without Choice Scarf get outspeed by Silvally-Poison and are quickly put in range of a +1 Surf.

Qwilfish: If Silvally-Poison isn't running Thunderbolt, it gets hard walled by Qwilfish, which can cripple it with paralysis and chip it down with Rocky Helmet damage.

Rock-types: If Silvally-Poison doesn't carry Surf, it can't significantly damage Coalossal and risks a Flame Body burn with its contact moves. On the other hand, if it does not have Thunderbolt, it struggles with Kabutops, which can hit it hard.

Mixed Walls: Very bulky Pokemon like Altaria, Miltank, and Uxie can stomach Silvally-Poison's hits and heavily damage it with their repeated attacks, even if Silvally-Poison can break through them after several boosts.

Steel-types: If Silvally-Poison isn't using Flamethrower, it can't really deal damage to Perrserker and Klinklang, and they can significantly weaken it with their powerful STAB moves.

Faster Attackers: Pokemon like Cinccino, Alolan Persian, and Rapidash outspeed Silvally-Poison and can 2HKO it while avoiding an OHKO from it.

sets.name: Work Up
sets.description:
Work Up Silvally-Poison is a powerful mixed attacker thanks to its great bulk and coveted Poison typing, which let it take advantage of common threats like Eldegoss, Alcremie, and Thwackey. Flamethrower lets Silvally-Poison 2HKO Tangela and OHKO Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang after a boost. Thunderbolt is an alternative for massive damage to Qwilfish, Kabutops, and Cramorant, the former resisting every other move Silvally-Poison commonly runs. Surf removes Ground- and Rock-types like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Coalossal after chip damage, as well as beating Rapidash without risking a burn from Flame Body.

Since Silvally-Poison misses a lot of OHKOs after a Work Up, it works better as a mid- or late-game wallbreaker, so it appreciates early-game wallbreakers like Black Belt Sawk and Thwackey weakening walls and removing their items with Knock Off. Rotom formes make for great partners, weakening Ground-types with Will-O-Wisp and their secondary STAB moves so Silvally-Poison can OHKO them later with Surf. Furthermore, most Electric-types like Rotom, Stunfisk, and Manectric can force in Grass-types like Thwackey, Eldegoss, and Tangela for Silvally-Poison to take advantage of. That said, Eldegoss and Tangela can put it to sleep with Sleep Powder on the switch, so Silvally-Poison should be careful setting up versus them. These Electric-types also take care of Steel-types for Silvally-Poison. Defensive pivots like Wishiwashi, Clefairy, and Tangela are appreciated to switch into revenge killers like Cinccino and Choice Scarf Sawk or defensive checks like Stunfisk and Miltank, in addition to providing it switch-in opportunities.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Silvally-Poison makes a good pivot with its great bulk and useful set of resistances letting it check attackers like Sawk and Thwackey. It is also one of the few Pokemon packing both a pivoting move and entry hazard removal, bringing great role compression. Surf lets it threaten common hazard setters such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Coalossal, while Thunderbolt hits Qwilfish, another premier Spikes setter.

Silvally-Poison's key defensive utility, along with its pivoting, makes it a premier choice for VoltTurn teams. As a result, other staples of this archetype like Wishiwashi, Rotom, and Basculin make for great partners to consistently chip the opposing team. Thwackey is a particularly noticeable partner, forcing in Grass-types such as Eldegoss and Tangela, which Silvally-Poison takes advantage of, and providing Grassy Terrain support, negating Silvally-Poison's weakness to Earthquake and providing it passive recovery. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Arctovish, and Jynx love getting safe switch-in opportunities from pivoting moves, and Silvally-Poison can switch into their checks like Sawk and Thwackey.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance Silvally-Poison doubles up as an offensive pivot and late-game cleaner. U-turn allows it to generate momentum and chip its checks like Rhydon and Alolan Persian early-game. Flame Charge lets it outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom, and it also provides coverage for Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang.

This set fits better on offensive teams due to how immediately threatening it is. It appreciates Pokemon able to take advantage of Rock-, Ground-, and Steel-types such as Thwackey, Basculin, and Sawk, which help it sweep late-game, while they enjoy Silvally-Poison forcing these checks in. Offensive pivots like Rotom, Articuno, and Cinccino make for great partners, forming VoltTurn cores with Silvally-Poison. Thievul is a noticeable partner that can heavily weaken physically bulky foes like Rhydon and Miltank, opening the way for a Silvally-Poison sweep, while in return Silvally-Poison can take advantage of the Fighting- and Fairy-types such as Sawk and Alcremie that Thievul forces in.

Thwackey.comments:
Other Options

Drain Punch is an option on Swords Dance sets,super effectively hitting Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang as well as Sap Sipper Bouffalant and Miltank. However, due to its low Base Power and the importance of Knock Off and U-turn for Thwackey's offensive pivot role, it is often not worth using. Terrain Extender is an option if paired with other Grassy Glide users like Flapple, Trevenant, and Gourgeist-S.
