However, teams built around Grassy Terrain are quite bad due to having few other ways to maximize the Terrain.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: The likes of Silvally-Poison, Skuntank, and Golbat resist Thwackey's STAB moves and U-turn and can take it out with their super effective STAB moves. However, the last one dislikes losing its Eviolite to Knock Off.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales outspeed and OHKO Thwackey with their super effective STAB moves. They also resist Thwackey's STAB moves and U-turn, even if they dislike switching into Knock Off. Due to Rapidash and Coalossal's ability in Flame Body, Thwackey is deterred from coming in and using U-turn, even if Coalossal doesn't resist its STAB moves.

Defensive Grass-types: Bulky Grass-types like Tangela, Eldegoss, and Appletun can take Thwackey's STAB moves. However, U-turn hits them quite hard. Additionally, Tangela dislikes losing its Eviolite to Knock Off, as this jeopardizes its ability to handle other physical attackers like Sawk and Silvally-Dark. Some bulky Grass-types like Gourgeist formes and Shiinotic don't mind U-turn as much but are less common, and Gourgeist-S must watch out for Knock Off instead.

Flying-types: Pokemon such as Articuno, Rotom-S, and Altaria can sponge Thwackey's STAB moves, resist U-turn, and retaliate with their super effective STAB moves, take advantage of it with Defog, or use their own pivoting moves.

Steel-types: Perrserker and Klinklang resist Thwackey's STAB moves and U-turn while sporting decent physical bulk, meaning they can comfortably switch into Thwackey and threaten it with their powerful STAB moves.

Sap Sipper: While quite scarce in the current metagame, Sap Sipper Bouffalant and Miltank are immune to Thwackey's STAB moves, making it very hard for it to clean late-game with Grassy Glide.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Thwackey is a versatile physical attacker, able to wallbreak, clean, and bring utility. Thanks to its Grassy Terrain, Grassy Glide is an amazing priority move that can OHKO faster offensive threats like Cinccino and Choice Scarf Rotom, as well as cleaning weakened teams. Grassy Terrain also makes Wood Hammer extremely hard to switch into, 2HKOing defensive behemoths like Uxie and Thick Fat Miltank, as well as common Grass-resistant Pokemon like Skuntank and Frosmoth. U-turn lets Thwackey weaken its checks like Skuntank, Eldegoss, and Rotom-S while keeping momentum. Knock Off removes Thwackey's checks' items, like Eviolite from Tangela and Golbat and Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno, Altaria, and Rapidash, jeopardizing their ability to come on Thwackey's STAB moves. Additionally, it provides reliable coverage for Gourgeist formes, notably always OHKOing standard Gourgeist-S after Stealth Rock.

This set pairs well in offensive teams with other VoltTurn users, from offensive ones like Perrserker, Morpeko, Rotom, and Silvally-Poison to defensive ones like Uxie, Rotom-S, and Wishiwashi. The resulting cores appreciate entry hazard support to further weaken teams and make up for Grassy Terrain's passive recovery, especially since Thwackey removes Heavy-Duty Boots from common users with Knock Off. Therefore, the likes of Qwilfish and Coalossal make for great partners, also handling some Thwackey checks like Unfezant and appreciating the Earthquake damage reduction from Grassy Terrain. Special wallbreakers like Thievul, Jynx, and Skuntank enjoy Thwackey creating switch-in opportunities with U-turn on the likes of Tangela, Altaria, and Gourgeist formes. Alternatively, Thwackey works well in physical spam teams with the likes of Sawk, Silvally formes, and Kangaskhan, since it can heavily cripple and damage physical behemoths like Tangela, Uxie, and Miltank.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Wielding an Eviolite, Thwackey has the bulk to perform several roles during the game. Swords Dance enables it to clean late-game with its STAB priority Grassy Glide, which is also quite useful mid-game to revenge kill weakened foes like Silvally formes, Sawk, and Rotom. Knock Off and U-turn let Thwackey be an early-game pivot, crippling checks like Tangela, Articuno, and Rapidash and keeping momentum with U-turn. However, the latter can punish Thwackey thanks to Flame Body. U-turn + Swords Dance allows Thwackey to take advantage of bulky Regenerator Grass-types in Tangela and Eldegoss, consistently threatening and weakening them.

Swords Dance Thwackey fits well in balance and bulky offense teams looking for an a secondary revenge killer, late-game cleaner, and check to Rhydon and Rotom. Entry hazard setters including Coalossal, Rhydon, and Qwilfish appreciate the passive recovery from Grassy Terrain and it weakening Earthquake from Kangaskhan and Sawk. In return, they can check some of Thwackey's checks such as Altaria, Rapidash, and Skuntank. Other pivots like Wishiwashi, Rotom, and Silvally formes are also great to form VoltTurn cores with Thwackey, pivoting on each others' checks. Special wallbreakers such as Thievul, Jynx, and Skuntank enjoy Thwackey bringing them safely on the field versus physical walls such as Altaria and Tangela. Other physical wallbreakers such as Swords Dance Silvally formes, especially Poison, appreciate Thwackey removing Tangela's Eviolite, and in return they can weaken physical walls, opening the way for a Thwackey sweep.

Thievul.comments:
Other Options

Thievul can be ran on Electric Terrain teams with Electric Seed, although the archetype isn't very effective. Thievul can use the combination of Throat Spray + Snarl or Sitrus Berry + Substitute to activate Unburden; however, these sets need several turns to set up and are often not worth using. Hyper Beam is Thievul's strongest move and an option on both sets to nuke Dark- and Fairy-types such as Silvally-Dark and Alcremie, but it is exploitable and gives the foe a free turn, and Thievul can outspeed and 2HKO most of these threats with its other moves. A Timid nature can be used on the Choice Specs set to give Thievul a better matchup against more offensive teams; however, a Modest nature lets Thievul break through special walls like Throh, Eviolite-less Clefairy, and Wishiwashi with a boost from Stakeout.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Thanks to their great special bulk and resistance to Thievul's STAB moves, Fairy-types such as Carbink, Alcremie, and Clefairy easily wall Thievul, even if non-specially defensive variants of them have to watch out for Stakeout-boosted Psychic.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Skuntank, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry tank Dark Pulse and Psychic and threaten Thievul. However, they aren't extremely reliable, as they still take heavy damage from Stakeout-boosted moves and Nasty Plot-boosted Burning Jealousy.

Fighting-types: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, Thievul fails to OHKO Fighting-types such as Poliwrath, Gurdurr, and Throh, which can take it out.

Faster Attackers: Due to its mediocre bulk, Choice Specs Thievul is forced out by faster attackers such as Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan.

Specially Defensive Walls: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, specially defensive walls such as Articuno and Wishiwashi can easily wall Thievul. However, Thievul can 2HKO them with its Stakeout- or Nasty Plot-boosted moves, so they have to be played carefully.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Thievul is a deadly wallbreaker thanks to the combination of Choice Specs and Stakeout. Psychic OHKOes Fighting-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath with a Stakeout boost and serves as its strongest move for Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy. Despite its low base power, Burning Jealousy is Thievul's strongest option for Dark-types such as Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian and lets Thievul force out Frosmoth. Knock Off is an alternative that cripples Eviolite-reliant walls such as Clefairy and Type: Null, letting Thievul beat them later with its other moves.

Thievul works best on offensive teams looking for a very powerful special wallbreaker. Physical wallbreakers such as Basculin, Rapidash, and Silvally formes can force in physical walls such as Qwilfish, Tangela, and Uxie, giving Thievul an opportunity to switch in. These partners can also break through specially defensive Pokemon that give Thievul a hard time, such as Clefairy, Articuno, and Alcremie. Since Fairy-, Dark-, and Fighting-types such as Clefairy, Silvally-Dark, and Sawk threaten Thievul, checks to these types, such as Rapidash, Gurdurr, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. VoltTurn users such as Wishiwashi, Uxie, and Rotom-S create opportunities for Thievul to activate Stakeout. Due to Thievul's average Speed tier, it struggles versus more offensive teams; therefore, fast Pokemon such as Cinccino and Choice Scarf Sawk make for great partners.

Eldegoss.comments:
Other Options

A specially defensive spread lets Eldegoss answer Rotom and special Basculin sets better; however, it comes at the cost of easily switching into Rhydon and Thwackey. Eject Button is an alternative item for more offensive teams that pairs well with Regenerator, providing Eldegoss with a one-time free switch to a teammate while making it Poltergeist-proof. Likewise, Eject Pack paired with Leaf Storm is an alternative; however, it usually doesn't work as well as Eject Button and forces Eldegoss to forgo a standard moveslot for Leaf Storm. Even without an Eject Pack, Leaf Storm is a stronger alternative to Giga Drain; however, Eldegoss's fire power is still mediocre, and the missing added recovery from Giga Drain often jeopardizes Eldegoss's sustainability.

Checks and Counters

Fire-, Flying-, and Poison-types: Fire-, Flying-, and Poison-type Pokemon resist Eldegoss's STAB moves and Pollen Puff, while being able to nail Eldegoss with their super effective STAB moves. This makes the likes of Rapidash, Rotom-S, and Silvally-Poison huge threats to it, even if most of them want to avoid being put to sleep by Sleep Powder.

Steel-types: Eldegoss is unable to deal significant damage to Steel-types that can easily break through Eldegoss, such as Perrserker and Klinklang even if they have to be wary of Sleep Powder. However, they can use it as setup fodder if Sleep Powder has already been used.

Ice-types: The likes of Abomasnow, Jynx, and Frosmoth can shred off Eldegoss with their powerful super effective STAB moves, even if most of them can't switch into Eldegoss's moves.

Strong Attackers: Despite its solid bulk, Eldegoss is 2HKOed by powerful attackers like Choice Band Gourgeist, and Swords Dance Sivally formes. However, Eldegoss can shut most them down with Sleep Powder.

Special Walls: Due to Eldegoss's lack of raw power and lack of access to Toxic, special walls like Throh, Articuno, and Clefairy can easily switch into it, even if they dislike getting put to sleep.

sets.name: Mixed Wall
sets.description:
Eldegoss is a premier Rapid Spinner in the ZU metagame, being able to force out common entry hazard setters like Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab, Rhydon, and Stunfisk. Pollen Puff allows Eldegoss to threaten Grass-types that resist Giga Drain such as Tangela, Thwackey, and Appletun. Sleep Powder lets Eldegoss cripple checks like Rapidash, Skuntank, and Articuno that attempt to switch into it. Aromatherapy provides clerical support to Eldagoss's team and also helps Eldegoss handle Will-O-Wisp Rotom. Synthesis is an alternative that lets Eldegoss rely less on Giga Drain and Regenerator to heal but doesn't let Eldegoss beat anything that it doesn't already beat. The combination of Heavy-Duty Boots and Regenerator makes Eldegoss hard to wear down, letting it act as an effective hazard remover the whole game. The Speed investment allows Eldegoss to outspeed Adamant Rhydon, and the rest of the EVs are put into physical bulk to let Eldegoss better take on physical attackers like Morpeko and Alolan Dugtrio.

Rapid Spin lets Eldegoss make up from other bulky Grass-types like Tangela and Gourgeist formes, making it better on entry hazard-stacking teams. Due to its average bulk, Eldegoss appreciates being paired with other walls in balance defensive cores; for instance, physical walls like Miltank and Qwilfish and special walls like Throh and Stunfisk that also appreciate Eldegoss's ability to remove entry hazards from the user's side only. Due to its many weaknesses, solid checks to diverse types are required‚Äîthe aforementioned Qwilfish helps with Steel- and Fire-types, Miltank helps with Fire- and Ice-types, and Stunfisk deals with Poison- and Steel-types. Rapid Spin is valuable for hazard-weak attackers such as Jynx and Unfezant, and in return, they make up for Eldegoss's passivity. Physical wallbreakers such as Perrserker, Silvally formes, and Cinccino also make for great partners, as they are able to force out special walls like Clefairy and Articuno.

Coalossal.comments:
Other Options

Will-O-Wisp allows Coalossal to consistently cripple opposing physical attackers, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Overheat is an alternative over Flamethrower, but its low PP and Special Attack drop make it less desirable than Flamethrower. Heat Crash is also a notable alternative, but Coalossal has trouble breaking Tangela with it. Similarly, Stone Edge can be used over Rock Blast, but its low PP and inaccuracy can be exploited by foes like Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Coalossal's 4x weakness to Water causes it to be threatened by the plethora of Water-types in ZU, such as Basculin, Qwilfish, and Wishiwashi. However, physical Water-types should be wary of being burned by Flame Body.

Ground-type Pokemon and Coverage: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Galarian Stunfisk are able to exploit Coalossal's 4x weakness to Ground and threaten it with Earthquake, which avoids Flame Body, or set up entry hazards. Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan and Sawk can OHKO Coalossal with Earthquake and not activate Flame Body. Opposing Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash often carry Ground-type coverage moves to threaten Coalossal.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath can threaten Coalossal with their STAB options, although they dislike being burned.

Knock Off: Coalossal heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to consistently switch in and remove entry hazards. Losing it, combined with its lack of recovery, allows it to get easily worn down.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Coalossal finds a distinct niche in ZU as a Spikes setter that provides good defensive utility against common foes such as Frosmoth, Articuno, and Rotom. It can force the aforementioned foes out to set up Spikes or remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Stealth Rock can be used if Coalossal is not paired with a Stealth Rock setter or if there is already a Rapid Spin user on the team. Rock Blast allows Coalossal to threaten Substitute users such as Frosmoth and Articuno and entry hazard removers such as Rotom-S and Altaria. Flamethrower lets Coalossal force out Tangela and Perrserker, giving it the opportunity to reliably use Rapid Spin. Flame Body deters physical attackers like Cinccino and Silvally from spamming their STAB moves, and it can potentially cripple threats such as Sawk and physical Basculin in an emergency situation.

Coalossal can provide both entry hazard setting and removal for certain bulky offense teams. As Coalossal has 4x weaknesses to both Water and Ground, it is recommended to pair Coalossal with Grass-types such as Tangela and Thwackey. Tangela is also able to tank hits from Fighting-types such as Sawk and Poliwrath, while Thwackey is able to provide passive recovery and reduce damage from Earthquake. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie and Alolan Persian can preserve Coalossal's Heavy-Duty Boots, letting it consistently pivot in to remove entry hazards; Uxie can also threaten the aforementioned Fighting-types.

Flapple.comments:
Other Options

An Adamant nature gives Flapple additional breaking power but leaves it outpaced by the likes of Frosmoth. A Choice Scarf set with a Jolly nature outpaces threats like Cinccino and Basculin, but it is still notably outpaced by Accelgor, faster Choice Scarf users like Sawk, and setup sweepers like +1 Silvally formes.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: While they can't switch-in directly, faster Pokemon like Rotom-S, Accelgor, and Skuntank are able to outspeed and OHKO Flapple due to its poor bulk and defensive typing.

Ice-type Moves: Flapple's 4x weakness to Ice leaves it easily disposed of by faster Ice-types such as Articuno and Cryogonal, while Piloswine is able to OHKO Flapple with its priority Ice Shard. This weakness also leaves it susceptible to Ice-type coverage such as Basculin's Ice Beam.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Klinklang and Perrserker resist both of Flapple's STAB moves.

Fairy-types: While Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy are unable to switch into Grav Apple, they can take advantage of Flapple if it locks itself into Outrage or Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Flapple is a devastating wallbreaker thanks to its solid offensive typing in tandem with its Hustle-boosted attacks, allowing it to dismantle defensive cores consisting of Pokemon like Pyukumuku, and Altaria. Grav Apple is Flapple's primary STAB move, with its Defense drop punishing switch-ins, reducing Flapple's reliance on prediction. A mixed Life Orb set with Draco Meteor allows Flapple to bypass Grass-resistant Pokemon and physical walls such as Altaria, Qwilfish, and Tangela. On the the other hand, a Choice Band set with Outrage handles specially bulky Grass-resistant Pokemon like Articuno and Frosmoth. Sucker Punch OHKOes faster offensive threats such as Choice Scarf Rotom as well as picking off Accelgor and Cinccino after some chip damage. Alternatively, Grassy Glide can be used on Grassy Terrain teams, threatening all faster Pokemon that do not resist Grass. Hustle does allow Flapple to 2HKO just about any Pokemon in the metagame, but its accuracy drop, combined with Flapple relying on a drawback-laden Draco Meteor or Outrage to dispatch Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Altaria, makes Flapple somewhat unreliable.

Flapple's poor bulk and defensive typing give it few direct switch-in opportunities, so it pairs well with bulky pivots that are able to bring it in safely such as Uxie, Wishiwashi, and Rotom-S. Coalossal and Qwilfish provide Flapple entry hazard support as well as pressuring Fairy-types like Alcremie and Clefairy. Special attackers such as Cramorant and Rotom appreciate Flapple's ability to pressure special walls like Wishiwashi and Stunfisk. In return, Cramorant provides entry hazard removal, while Rotom forms an effective VoltTurn core with Flapple. Ninetales and Rapidash easily handle Ice- and Steel-types like Articuno, Klinklang, and Perrserker that Flapple struggles with, while Flapple can break down their checks such as Altaria and Wishiwashi. Late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Silvally formes appreciate Flapple's ability to break walls such as Wishiwashi and Pyukumuku. Flapple works well on Grassy Terrain teams, supporting its teammates by threatening conventional Grass-type checks like Altaria.

Cramorant.comments:
Other Options

Hurricane is an alternative to Brave Bird that is weaker against Frosmoth, but stronger against physically bulky Pokemon such as Poliwrath and Qwilfish. Substitute synergizes well with Gulp Missile, helping Cramorant reach the range for its Gorging forme; however, it is generally less effective than Cramorant's other moves. An offensive spread of 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe can be utilized with Hurricane to better offensively pressure foes such as Tangela and Gurdurr.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom and Rotom-S can OHKO Cramorant.

Strong Attackers: Although they dislike taking damage and a potential paralysis from Gulp Missile, strong attackers such as Silvally-Dark and Kangaskhan are capable of easily KOing Cramorant.

Toxic: Toxic from foes like Wishiwashi and Miltank, as residual damage does not activate Gulp Missile.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Cramorant finds a niche in ZU as a Defogger, threatening common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Piloswine. Roost is necessary to improve Cramorant's longevity and lets it consistently switch into the likes of Accelgor and Poliwrath. Surf activates Gulp Missile, allowing Cramorant to punish attackers, and can potentially paralyze them if Gulp Missile is activated when it has no more than 50% HP. Brave Bird complements Surf by weakening foes such as Qwilifish and Wishiwashi while ignoring Ice Scales from Frosmoth, letting Cramorant OHKO it; Brave Bird also benefits from Gulp Missile lowering the foe's Defense stat when Cramorant is above 50% HP.

Although Cramorant is an effective Defogger, its 4x weakness to Electric makes it susceptible to Rotom formes. Checks to them such as Rhydon and Piloswine are appreciated; Rhydon can also check Kangaskhan. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes and Alolan Persian can improve Cramorant's longevity and let it consistently clear entry hazards by keeping Heavy-Duty Boots intact; in return, the former two appreciate Cramorant checking Frosmoth and the latter values it threatening opposing Ground-types. Cramorant's ability to inflict paralysis with Gulp Missile at low HP complements slow wallbreakers like Perrserker and Skuntank and aids them against fast attackers like Cinccino and Sawk. Powerful attackers such as Silk Scarf Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Cinccino appreciate Cramorant's Defog letting them consistently switch into battle.

Hattrem.comments:
Other Options

Hattrem has a very wide movepool with options like Aromatherapy, and Calm Mind. However, getting rid off one of the standard moves comes with a lot of opportunity cost and is not advisable.

Checks and Counters

Item Removal: Hattrem relies on its Eviolite to reliably wall entry hazard setters such as defensive Rhydon and Piloswine and should avoid getting crippled by Knock Off users such as Gurdurr and Sawk.

Offensive Entry Hazard Setters: Foes such as Accelgor and offensive Rhydon easily muscle through Hattrem and can set up entry hazards against it, though Rhydon must be aware of Giga Drain.

Dark-, Ghost-, and Bug-type Pokemon and Coverage: Pokemon such as Shiftry, Rotom, and Accelgor easily defeat Hattrem with their super effective STAB moves.

sets.name: Stall Support
sets.description:
Hattrem is the best user of Magic Bounce in ZU, carving it a niche as a unique form of entry hazard control. Psychic threatens most entry hazard setters, especially Qwilfish. Mystical Fire provides coverage for Rhydon and Piloswine while providing some recovery. Rest is Hattrem's best form of recovery and lets it PP stall entry hazard setters it struggles to defeat with its offensive moves, like Galarian Stunfisk. Sleep Talk prevents Hattrem from being completely passive after using Rest. A physically defensive spread is preferred, as most entry hazard setters are physical attackers.

Hattrem fits best on defensive teams that heavily dislike entry hazards. Pokemon that are very susceptible to entry hazards like Alcremie, Cofagrigus, and Golbat enjoy Hattrem consistently keeping entry hazards off the field. A secondary remover such as Articuno, Altaria, or Cramorant is required to handle entry hazard setters like Accelgor and Rhydon, which can break through Hattrem. Solid physical and special walls such as Tangela, Pyukumuku and Stunfisk are needed, as Hattrem tends to invite in wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Shiftry, and Rotom due to its average bulk and mediocre offensive presence.

Perrserker.comments:
Other Options

An Assault Vest set capitalizes on Perrserker's resistances and checks Pokemon like Alcremie, Frosmoth, and Appletun more reliably, though Perrserker will miss out on a lot of power.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Poliwrath, Wishiwashi, and Qwilfish don't take much damage from Iron Head and U-turn and can safely switch into Perrserker. The former two can deal massive damage to it with their STAB moves, while the latter can freely set up Spikes or paralyze it with Thunder Wave. However, Poliwrath and Wishiwashi need to be careful of switching into a Choice Band-boosted Close Combat or Seed Bomb, while Qwilfish should be wary of switching into Lash Out.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Stunfisk, Rotom formes, Manectric, and Raichu can take advantage of Perrserker's low Speed and special bulk while resisting its STAB move. Stunfisk also deters its pivoting with Static, and the Rotom formes can pivot against it with Volt Switch or burn it with Will-O-Wisp. However, only Stunfisk can reliably switch in repeatedly.

Fire-types: Rapidash and Ninetales outspeed and OHKO Perrserker with their Fire-type STAB moves while resisting Perrserker's STAB move. Rapidash also deters it with Flame Body, which can cripple its offensive capabilities. However, both of them can get OHKOed by Choice Band-boosted Close Combat.

Fighting-types: A healthy Gurdurr is bulky enough to stomach a Choice-Band boosted Iron Head; it can then retaliate with its STAB moves. While Sawk and Silvally-Fighting cannot directly switch into Perrserker, they outpace and can OHKO it with their STAB moves.

Faster Wallbreakers: Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio, Basculin, and some Silvally formes can outspeed and KO Perrserker with some prior chip damage, though none of them want to directly switch into any of its attacks.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Perrserker is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its powerful Choice Band-boosted Iron Head. Close Combat OHKOes Coalossal and targets Steel-type Pokemon resistant to Iron Head like Klinklang, Galarian Stunfisk, and opposing Perrserker. It also offers strong neutral coverage. U-turn pivots out of Pokemon Perrserker has difficulty breaking through, such as Poliwrath and Gurdurr, while simultaneously chipping them. Lash Out is the preferred last move since it nails Rotom and incoming Qwilfish, which would otherwise wall it completely. Alternatively, Seed Bomb is Perrserker's best option against Poliwrath, Wishiwashi, and Stunfisk, and it avoids the latter from paralyzing it with Static. Tough Claws strengthens all listed moves besides Seed Bomb, making Close Combat a pseudo-secondary STAB move that hits Steel-resistant Pokemon harder, while Steely Spirit boosts Iron Head's power to frightening levels.

Perrserker's low Speed and high Attack make it a great slow wallbreaker for VoltTurn teams. Pivots such as Rotom formes, Alolan Persian, Wishiwashi, and Uxie can help it get on the field safely. In return, Perrserker can threaten passive Pokemon like Miltank, Clefairy, and Articuno. Perrserker also gets revenge killed easily by Fire- and Fighting-types like Rapidash, Ninetales, and Sawk, so Pokemon like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Tangela are appreciated to handle them. Clerics such as Miltank and Alcremie can allow Perrserker to pivot more freely against Flame Body and Static Pokemon, like Rapidash, Coalossal, and Stunfisk.

sets.name: Swords Dance + Substitute
sets.description:
Leftovers Perrserker forgoes Choice Band's immediate power to get more longevity as a wallbreaker. The combination of Substitute and Swords Dance exploits foes that rely on status or utility moves to damage it, such as Tangela, Articuno, and Uxie. Close Combat provides coverage against Steel-types, such as Klinklang, opposing Perrserker, and Galarian Stunfisk. The EV spread allows it to outspeed standard Alcremie while preventing Tangela, Uxie, and non-Flamethrower Altaria from breaking its Substitute.

Perrserker should enter the field against Pokemon that cannot affect it much, such as Altaria, Klinklang, and Eldegoss, though it should scout for coverage moves. It should come in through a teammate that has fainted or by pivoting through VoltTurn cores. Examples of such pivots are Wishiwashi, Clefairy, and Rotom formes. Clerics like Altaria and Alcremie allow Perrserker to wallbreak more should it get statused; Altaria is especially notable for covering Perrserker's defensive weaknesses. Physical cleaners, like Sawk and Gourgeist-S, take advantage of Perrserker weakening walls like Clefairy and Altaria to sweep late-game more easily.

Alcremie.comments:
Other Options

Alcremie can run a specially defensive set, making good use of its insane special bulk, access to Aromatherapy, and immunity to Taunt; however, this set is usually outclassed by Clefairy, which has Magic Guard and a superior support movepool. Draining Kiss, while far weaker than Dazzling Gleam, makes Alcremie less reliant on Recover. Flame Orb can be used to avoid Toxic without resorting to Rest or Aromatherapy, but the constant chip damage jeopardizes Alcremie's bulk and limits its setup opportunities.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Unless Alcremie is carrying a Psychic move, Poison-types like Poison Jab Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison can take on its attacks and retaliate back with their super effective STAB moves. However, passive ones like defensive Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab and Golbat lacking Toxic are usually unable to beat Alcremie, especially Double Dance sets. Skuntank is noteworthy, as its Psychic immunity allows it to handle every Alcremie variant.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang can take an unboosted Mystical Fire from Alcremie and OHKO back with their super effective STAB moves. They can even break through Acid Armor Alcremie by setting up.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Dazzling Gleam and Mystical Fire. They easily break through Alcremie with their STAB moves or use it as setup fodder.

Physical Wallbreakers: Even with maximum Defense investment, Alcremie is unable to take on powerful physical wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Thwackey, and Cinccino. However, it can easily wall most of them after Acid Armor.

Dark-types: Even though Dark-types such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry are obliterated by Dazzling Gleam, they completely wall Alcremie's Double Dance set thanks to their immunity to Stored Power. They can take advantage of it to set up.

sets.name: Defensive Calm Mind + Recover
sets.description:
Calm Mind Alcremie serves as a physical wall that is able to check foes like Sawk, Shiftry, and Gurdurr thanks to its typing while doubling as a threatening setup sweeper. Mystical Fire threatens Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker, which take little damage from Dazzling Gleam, while also heavily damaging Frosmoth. Alternatively, Aromatherapy allows Alcremie to sponge status and break through walls like Toxic Clefairy while also supporting partners that dislike getting statused, such as Miltank, Tangela, and Coalossal. However, without Mystical Fire, Alcremie is unable to beat Steel-types. Aroma Veil provides a Taunt immunity, allowing Alcremie to set up against foes such as Golbat and Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab. Sweet Veil is an option, giving Alcremie an immunity to sleep-inducing moves used by Tangela, Eldegoss, and Jynx.

Alcremie fits well on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its sweeping potential and defensive utility as a Fairy-type. Ground-types like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk threaten Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skuntank. Partners such as Cramorant and Altaria deal with Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which can break through Alcremie. Teammates such as Rapidash, Qwilfish, and Manectric, which can check Steel-types, also make for great partners. Strong special wallbreakers such as Basculin, Thievul, and Frosmoth can heavily weaken special walls, putting them in range of Alcremie's attacks. This can be very important if Alcremie is not running Aromatherapy to disregard Toxic from threats such as Clefairy and Wishiwashi.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description:
Double Dance Alcremie is great against stall and balance teams and has the potential to muscle through most teams once Dark-types have been removed. The combination of Calm Mind and Acid Armor bolsters Alcremie's bulk and Stored Power's base power to incredible levels. Stored Power is preferred for its ability to bypass Unaware Pyukumuku. Rest is used over Recover in order to play around Toxic and other status moves. Leftovers provides passive recovery, which is extremely valuable when Alcremie is asleep for two turns. However, Chesto Berry is an alternative that lets Alcremie fully heal once without drawback.

Because of Alcremie's inability to hit Dark-types, this set appreciates teammates weakening them. Attackers such as Thievul, Gourgeist-Small, and Shiftry can weaken Dark-types, especially with entry hazard support from setters such as Qwilfish, Piloswine, and Stunfisk. Toxic Spikes from Runerigus and Qwilfish put Dark-types on a timer, although Skuntank is immune to them and some Dark-types like Morpeko run Heavy-Duty Boots. Fighting-types such as Gurdurr, Poliwrath, and Sawk check Dark- and Steel-types for Alcremie. Leftovers variants of Alcremie value having a sturdy defensive core to counteract its passivity and benefits from partners like Tangela and Altaria. Offensive Steel-types, mainly Perrserker and Klinklang, need to removed before Alcremie can sweep; therefore, teammates such as Rapidash and Sawk are appreciated.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Offensive Alcremie is the best choice for an offensive Fairy-type. Mystical Fire nails Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang and 2HKOes Frosmoth. Psychic destroys Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Golbat, while Calm Mind lets Alcremie break through special walls like Articuno and Clefairy. Heavy-Duty Boots makes it easier for Alcremie to utilize its great defensive typing and switch in against foes like Thievul, Sawk, and Gurdurr, while Life Orb makes Alcremie a better wallbreaker.

Dark-types such as Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Morpeko enjoy Alcremie's ability to take on Fighting- and Dark-types such as Gurdurr and Alolan Persian. Physical wallbreakers such as Cinccino and Choice Band Basculin can force in physical walls and pivot, providing Alcremie with wallbreaking opportunities, while also threatening special walls such as Clefairy, which can handle Alcremie. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine check Fire- and Poison-types such as Rapidash and Silvally-Poison. Partners such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Appletun can also wall problematic Fire-types for Alcremie.

Frosmoth.comments:
Other Options

Bug Buzz can be used as a secondary STAB move to better damage foes like Uxie, but it is usually not needed; Frosmoth's other coverage moves are better, and having both STAB attacks is less effective due to overlapping resistances. Weather Ball is a good option on weather teams, giving Frosmoth coverage it usually doesn't have access to.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash are the best offensive answer against Frosmoth, easily OHKOing it due to its 4x weakness. Frosmoth will also have to watch out for Pokemon with Fire-type coverage such as Fire Blast Skuntank and Mystical Fire Alcremie.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang can take on most of Frosmoth's attacks and threaten it back with their Steel-type moves.

Knock Off: Removing Frosmoth's Heavy-Duty Boots will heavily hinder its ability to sweep, as it will be susceptible to all type of entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock. Passive Pokemon like Clefairy and Tangela may bait in Frosmoth and remove its item.

Revenge Killers: Frosmoth's mediocre Speed and lackluster physical bulk make it easy to revenge kill, even at +1, by Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Gourgeist-S. Priority users like Kangaskhan, Shiftry, and Aqua Jet Basculin are able to revenge kill Frosmoth with minimal chip damage, although none of them can switch into Frosmoth's attacks with ease.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description:
Frosmoth is a great setup sweeper and offensive presence in the metagame thanks to its strong Special Attack, decent coverage, and access to Quiver Dance. Giga Drain threatens Water-types like Poliwrath and Wishiwashi, doing significant damage after a single boost. Substitute allows Frosmoth to set up on passive Pokemon that relies on status it to wear it down like Clefairy, Uxie, and Pyukumuku. Substitute also makes Frosmoth an excellent stallbreaker. Hurricane is an alternative to deal great damage to Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash. However, without Substitute, Frosmoth has significantly less opportunities to set up and is easier to revenge kill.

Frosmoth fits on balance and bulky offense teams that want a setup sweeper and soft check to special attackers such as Rotom. Switch-ins to Fire-types are great partners; Pokemon like Qwilfish and Thick Fat Appletun can switch into Ninetales and Rapidash, respectively. Fighting-types like Gurdurr and Poliwrath can switch into Rock- and Steel-types like Rhydon and Klinklang, while Frosmoth in return can set up on foes like Uxie and Tangela that switch into them. Secondary sweepers like Alcremie and Silvally formes can pressure foes and weaken them for Frosmoth to sweep late-game; they also pressure Frosmoth's checks such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Galarian Stunfisk. Qwilfish can absorb and scout for Knock Off users while setting entry hazards for Frosmoth to sweep.

Morpeko.comments:
Other Options

Taunt prevents Pokemon such as Uxie and Miltank from setting entry hazards and foes such as Altaria and Rotom-S from recovering health or using Defog. Life Orb grants Morpeko the freedom to switch between its moves, but the recoil can bring it in range of priority moves such as Basculin's Aqua Jet. Also, the decrease in damage output compared to Choice Band leaves Morpeko unable to reliably 2HKO Pokemon such as Altaria.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Bulky Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk are able to take most of Morpeko's attacks and force it out. However, they need to be healthy enough to tank a hit from Aura Wheel in Hangry Mode.

Grass-types: Defensive Grass-types such as Tangela, Eldegoss, and Appletun are able to take a hit from Morpeko and either cripple it with status or force it out.

Physically Defensive Walls: While they are unable to switch into Choice Band Aura Wheel, Morpeko struggles to break through physical walls such as Miltank and Altaria. Other physically bulky Pokemon such as Colbur Berry Cofagrigus and physically defensive Alcremie are able to withstand an attack and OHKO Morpeko.

Revenge Killers: Morpeko is susceptible to revenge killers, especially priority users, due to its poor bulk. Priority users such as Kangaskan, Gurdurr, and Basculin are to pick it off after it is weakened, while certain Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Silvally are able to revenge kill Morpeko if it lacks a Speed boost.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Morpeko is a unique offensive threat thanks to its signature move Aura Wheel and typing giving it a resistance to common revenge killers like Choice Scarf Rotom and Sucker Punch Shiftry. Aura Wheel gives Morpeko +1 Speed after each use, allowing it to outpace offensive threats like Rapidash and Cinccino to clean weakened teams late-game. Crunch provides Morpeko with a reliable Dark-type STAB move, hitting foes such as Gourgeist formes and Rotom. Seed Bomb is Morpeko's best coverage against opposing Ground-types, granting it a 2HKO against Piloswine and Rhydon after Stealth Rock damage.

Ground-types are able to play around Aura Wheel and must be eliminated before Morpeko can effectively clean. Water-types such Poliwrath, Qwilfish, and Wishiwashi pair well with Morpeko, as they weaken Ground-types and benefit from Morpeko's ability to pressure Pokemon like Rotom and Articuno. Special attackers like Jynx and Choice Specs Basculin are also able to handle the aforementioned Ground-types and eliminate physically defensive walls such as Acid Armor Alcremie and Tangela. These special attackers also appreciate Morpeko weakening bulky Water-types such as Poliwrath, Pyukumuku, and Wishiwashi.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
Morpeko holds a niche as a Rapid Spin user on offensive teams, handling some common entry hazard setters such as Uxie and Qwilfish. It also threatens Ghost-types such as Cofagrigus, Rotom, and Gourgeist formes, which other Rapid Spin users such as Coalossal and Eldegross do not do as effectively. However, Morpeko has a poor matchup against other entry hazard setters, especially Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk, which limit its effectiveness. Aura Wheel serves as Morpeko's strongest STAB move, hitting foes like Qwilfish, Cramorant, and Articuno in Full Belly Mode and Uxie and Rotom in Hangry Mode. Protect allows Morpeko to safely switch between its Full Belly and Hangry formes while also allowing it to scout moves from Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Sawk. Parting Shot pairs well with the Speed boost provided by Aura Wheel and allows Morpeko to pivot from unfavorable matchups.

Morpeko works best on offensive entry hazard stacking teams that appreciate its Rapid Spin and pivot support. Entry hazard setters such as Qwilfish, Coalossal, and Rhydon synergize well with Morpeko, the former checking Fighting-types such as Sawk and Fairy-types such as Clefairy; in return, Morpeko is able to handle foes like Rotom and Cramorant. Piloswine is able to wear down opposing Ground-types like Rhydon and set Stealth Rock. Wallbreakers like Jynx and Flapple appreciate Morpeko luring walls like Tangela and Altaria and bringing them in with Parting Shot. Attackers such as Kangaskan and setup sweepers such as Silvally-Poison enjoy Morpeko's Rapid Spin support.
